column10: b"b' So how do we make Markdown more user-friendly?'"

column12: bug tracker (eg jira)

column15: I\\\'d say the biggest issue is that its not "natural". (For example
column16: as much as I hate bbcode

column18: and I still have to look it up every time to remember if its (name)[url] or (url)[name] or [name](url) or...) The other issue is that the docs point to a page where most of the language isn\\\'t implemented yet.. (I added a page to the main wiki with what is implemented
column19: translated from a german link I got off IRC. I haven\\\'t checked to see if its complete
column20: but from my experience it is.) A lesser contributing issue is the lack of preview there is no way to see if you guessed correctly on formatting.. To bring this back home a little
column21: an editor would allow things like smart link processing \\\'insert link\\\' offer url shortening

column23: etc. And it makes it obvious to the user every time what features are and are not available without forcing them to learn yet another formatting language.\''

column10: b'b\' If the concept of Diaspora is really to protect our privacy life
column11: I propose my ideal way for photo-tagging : When a user upload a picture with friends on the pictures : 1Diaspora should auto-detect faces on photos ( url  ) 2The user should identify each person on the picture (if the auto-face recognition fail
column12: he can correct it) 3All faces should be extracted and each of them should be saved in independant files (3 peoples on the photo means 3 more files). We also keep the "x
column13: y" coordinates of the top left corner for each faces. 4All faces should be automatically blurred on the picture and saved like that on the server (to prevent any browser plugin to bypass the blurring system
column14: and prevent the right-click / save picture option). 5Diaspora notify each tagged persons to ask them the autorisation to show their face on this picture. 6The picture is immediatly visible on the user publisher wall / album
column15: but every faces are blurred. The list of users tagged on the picture are not yet visible for the public. 7Each tagged user have received a notification
column16: and they can answer "I Accept" or "I Refuse". (future options : always accept from this contact
column17: accept only for my mutual friends or friends in aspect X
column18: Y
column19: Z etc...) 8When a tagged user accept
column20: then his name is show under the picture
column21: and his small picture is now show on the top of the global picture
column22: to the exact "x
column23: y" coordinates. Then he can again change is mind
column24: and refuse again
column25: or re-accept later etc. May be a special link "download picture" could be usefull
column26: where we generate a picture of the current visible state. What do you think about my idea ?\''

column10: b'b" To me it seems that selecting only one pod could be problematic. What if a businessman wants to use diaspora\\\\* and often travels between Europe and US. So when he selects a US pod he\'ll have lag from Europe
column11: and vice versa. Considering migration stuff etc. wouldn\'t it make sense that a person can manage the pods that  is using?  For example: I know I\'m often traveling between Japan
column12: Europe and US. I\'d like my data to be on pods in each of those areas so I won\'t suffer lag. Subsequently
column13: data would be synced between these selected pods. This also guarantees some resilience in case one server dies. There comes into play another problem: Logging into your account. A great feature would be to be able to login to your pod from one website (which knows which email belongs to what pod(s) somehow) and automatically routes you to the correct pod. Otherwise you\'d need to switch between different websites all the time -A further connected issue: I just signed in to diaspora and saw that there\'s an e-mail with ones name attached to the pod. Not sure what it is used for actually
column14: but what is that e-mail worth if it\'s going to change when migrating to another pod (or using multiple pods)? So what I\'m suggesting is a framework to allow multiple pods to be selected by users and synced between each other. A one-point login to your correct pod (depending on your location?) would help to mitigate annoying domain-switching."'

column21: diaspora_federation [is moving]url  towards using as a field name for this matter.It was described in the ["UI for the account migration" section]url  After a user have provided an archive to the new pod he is forwarded to a page with a form similar to our present registration form
column22: with the difference that email address is prefilled with the value from the archive. Also
column23: profile information is being imported from the archive as was described in the ["Archive import sequence" section]url I drew a block diagram to make the process more detailed
column24: it is in the ["Updating DB state of a diaspora* pod when performing ID change" section]url  now. There is no point in removing "all user contents"
column25: because some of the content have relation to other people
column26: and will be rereferenced to the new identity anyway. Only some of the user content may be removed from the old home pod
column28: see ["Updating DB state of a diaspora* pod when performing ID change" section]url The old pod get the new profile just like any other pod
column29: by receiving the message.It\\\'s unclear why you say "archive import a step that can be done after the account is moved ... as specified later in the document". There is no such claims neither in the previous version of the spec
column30: nor in the new. Archive import is performed along with the moving process
column31: it may begin just after the new user record has been created
column32: and the AccountRename federation message is only sent when the archive is already imported.Archive is validated before the migration process ever started. I see no deadlocks here. We read the archive when the user provides it at the very beginning and use data from it to create a new account. The ID change doesn\\\'t depend on the archive data
column33: except of the step where the federation message is sent to the contacts
column34: which can easily be postponed until the import is finished. This very sequence was described in the previous version as well.\''

column10: b'b" I\'ll continue the account migration question in this topic.  I was asked about whether it will be possible to migrate from pods which stuck at the old versions (e.g.  which is 0.5.10.2).  1. It is possible to migrate
column11: and then manually close account at the old pod 2. Should we process this case automatically? We could check whether the version of remote old home pod is below and send there rather than  . This is something we could implement in But in this case
column12: ancient pod will dispatch messages
column13: so: 3. If some pod receives message while it has for the same account there already
column14: this should be rejected (that\'s a validation that we could actually add to  ). 4. There is a slight chance in this case that the old home will dispach account deletion earlier that some pod will receive account migration from the new home. So maybe we should add a 0.5-1 hour delay before performing account deletion received by the federation? Or we could only do that for deletions received from ancient pods."'

column10: b"b' Hm but the account archive on 0.5 is not enough to recreate the user
column11: is it?'"

column10: b'b" Well
column11: private key and diaspora id is enough to recreate the user
column12: though this user won\'t have any old data left. But I think that could be acceptable for people who are left on an abandonded pod. Otherwise they could only start a new account which won\'t have any old data as well.  Also we can use archive generated by version 0.5 after converting it to the archive format 2.0 version introduced for 0.7. This would save some of the data (users posts). "'

column10: b'b"  The archive from 0.5.x didn\'t contain the private key. Users on a pod with 0.5.x stop federating now with the release of 0.7.0.0
column11: so they can\'t wait until 0.8.0.0 is released
column12: they need to migrate **now** if the podmin doesn\'t upgrade.  Also: I don\'t want to add a lot of extra code and hacks for years old pods. The hack with the could work
column13: but as you already wrote
column14: it\'s error prone ... We can\'t add compatibility for everything that existed once.  Yes
column15: it\'s sad that some podmins don\'t want to maintain their pods anymore
column16: but I think that\'s not our business. And the user is still able to manually migrate to a modern maintained pod (manually add their contacts again
column17: like it was always done in the past). When they migrate to a 0.7.0.0 pod it would be the last time they need to do that."'

column10: b'b"  Oh
column11: I thought [this commit]url  was included in some of 0.5.x versions but apparently you\'re right.  But we still need to do this so that we have validations agains inconsistent federation message flow (imagine someone imports from 0.6.x pod and then deletes their account manually): > If some pod receives AccountDeletion message while it has AccountMigration for the same account there already
column12: this AccountDeletion should be rejected (that\'s a validation that we could actually add to 0.7.0.0)."'

column10: b'b"  Yes
column11: that\'s something we should do anyway
column12: not specific to the migration. We should block new messages if the account is closed
column13: but I\'m not sure if we should allow exceptions. For example still allow retractions: The AccountDeletion only deletes posts
column14: not comments (and that\'s intentional). If you still have your private key and want to remove a specific comment
column15: that would then theoretically be possible with manual things to send a retraction. I also don\'t think we have a disadvantage to still allow to receive retractions from closed accounts
column16: because for the migration
column17: all content was migrated away from the old person
column18: so a evil old podmin can\'t do any harm by sending retractions
column19: because the author doesn\'t match anymore.  But I also that think that\'s something that doesn\'t need to be added to 0.7.0.0 (it\'s already frozen and it\'s nothing critical. If we receive a deletion for an already migrated account
column20: there is nothing left to delete
column21: so nothing happens). So I think we can work on this in 0.7.1.0."'

column10: b"b'  Okay
column11: I think I can take care of it.'"

column10: b'b"  I agree that we can allow retractions for closed accounts. I don\'t see any other message type which need to be allowed though.  Also do you think we should send  /  back to the sender in case when we receive a message for the closed account? This could improve consistency in case when pods missed this message for whatever reason."'
b'b"  Yes
column11: that\'s a great idea. \\xf0\\x9f\\x91\\x8d "'

column10: b'b" So we happen to pass the signature signed with the new key to the old pod in the body. If the old pod keeps the signature in the DB
column11: then actually everyone can fetch the from the old pod at every moment
column12: including the case of pushing this entity to the pods which still aren\'t aware of the migration for some reason and send messages to the old user.  However I think it is useful to allow the entity to be fetched from the new pod as well
column13: because the old pod can go down. However
column14: if we don\'t want to keep the old private key at the new pod
column15: we can swap the  signature use for the  . So in terms of the protocol
column16: along with how it works now we allow to be the new person and to be the signature of the old person. This way we need to keep only the old person signature in the DB and actually reuse the same storage approach that old pods will use to store the signatures for the new people. Old person signature can be calculated at the time when migration object is created at the new pod and we don\'t need to store the old key at the new pod. We still need to add an optional property to the entity to allow this case
column17: but that shouldn\'t be a problem."'

column10: b'b" The main barrier to implementing  functionality has been
column11: as I understand it
column12: the flaws in federation. Federation is not yet at the point at which everyone on every pod will reliably see the most up-to-date data. If you can\'t be sure that you will be shown the latest
column13: accurate information on who is attending an event or even be sure that the date
column14: time and venue information you are shown is accurate (because if someone changed it since it was originally federated to your pod
column15: you might not be seeing the latest version)
column16: an events feature is next to useless. Of course someone is welcome to create it
column17: but everyone who used it would have to use it with the caveat that they might be seeing incorrect information. To my mind that is likely to be such a big problem that it is likely to be a blocker to such a feature being merged into the main code base. To have a feature in Diaspora which was \'broken\' in this way would be likely to put many people off using Diaspora. Of course
column18: the situation would be different in the case where everyone involved in an event was on the same pod (say a pod run for a club or society)
column19: as federation wouldn\'t be an issue. It might be that the best thing is for someone to create in a fork an events feature which will work only on individual pods
column20: and podmins who wanted to implement it only for their pod\'s members could pull that fork. This code could then later be merged in to the code base when federation were reliable and instant enough across all pods."'

column10: b'b" Hey @efstrian ! This feature is very much requested
column11: thank you for your interest in working on it! Before you start hammering out too much code
column12: it would be a fantastic idea to draw up a little plan on what exactly needs to be done and how it will be done. This makes sure that you don\'t write a huge amount of code that cannot be used. Also
column13: when you start writing code
column14: _please_ create a pull request with the code in the _very early stages_
column15: so we can follow the progress and give comments. There is nothing worse than someone writing lots of code and then the core team saying it cannot be used.. ;) As for the feature
column16: I\'d suggest splitting the implementation into as small pieces as possible. Maybe something like; Phase 1 Models and initial implementationCreate
column17: update and view events  This includes all the bits needed to not only create the event but also how it is shown in the stream
column18: single post view
column19: mobile
column20: etc. Personally I think you could follow up how polls work
column21: so events would be just additional details to a normal status message object. So instead of having some Facebook type dedicated very different Event object
column22: just allow the attachment of Event specific details _to_ a status message. This should be talked through before implementing so that we are clear what events actually are.Participate in an eventView upcoming eventsNo invitations at this stage though event post can be shared like any otherNo editing of events at this stage
column23: but of course they can be commented on. Phase 2 Event invitationsInvite other users to an eventProcess received invitation Phase 3 Event maintenanceEditing an event. Note this would require
column24: if made as a status message
column25: first editing functionality to appear. It is being worked on so it should be ready this hopefully Phase 4 AdministratorsAdd / remove administrators Splitting the feature into smaller tasks will allow for it to be implemented earlier and with less danger in breaking other parts. Also
column26: it is important to note that in all steps federation needs to be considered. Before deciding on the models and features for events you need to consider how the federation layer will be changed to support those features. I strongly feel events should be additional implementation on top of status messages
column27: not completely separate objects. What do others think? "'

column10: b'b\' Diaspora lacks killer features
column11: besides privacy and obviously that is not a killer feature or people would have come already. Events could be such a feature as others have mentioned
column12: but that means making events better than exists today
column13: not just copying what\\\'s already is out there.  Today I look for events in many places: I subscribe to some public calendars
column14: there are FB events
column15: meetup events
column16: some are shared via email and some via some specialized services. With a good implementation
column17: most of these could happen on D*.  Make it possible to post a public calendar to D* and then D* will mirror the calendar\\\'s events in the future. The sender is the poster or group (when those arrive). Let the poster add missing fields (like one theater\\\'s public calendar data could be complimented with the address and name of the theater
column18: links to the home page etc). When groups arrive
column19: each event should have its own group connected of course for participants to discuss before and after the event
column20: just like meetup & FB events.  With an embeddable web view for the published calendar
column21: the publisher could get the ability to have comments
column22: increasing D*s exposure. This would also bring in "free" content and it would increase the value of a public calendar. This is not something FB or meetup can do today I think.  A public calendar could be posted by just posting the calendar\\\'s URL. Add some field under the post for the user to add default content for the events (like address
column23: URL
column24: title etc). There could be a link back from events to the "calendar publishing" for the publisher to  the calendar later on (and then chose to remove future events or all events).  When a user publishes a public calendar that someone else has already published
column25: allow it
column26: but mention it for the user. "It has been published before
column27: subscribe instead?". Having the calendar published fewer times makes discussions about the events more  ("Hey
column28: is anyone going to the show from X
column30: but the first to publish it should not monopolize it
column31: preventing the owner of the public calendar from later publishing it to D* or requiring manual intervention.  Make it possible to search & subscribe (recurrent search) to events filtered on
column32: distance  publisher. With FB their algorithms decide for you
column33: making you miss events. Although sometimes good
column34: many want better control.  With FB events you never know how many people show up. It has become better
column35: but now people just press "interested" and sometimes still show up. "Interested" gives good info
column36: but there should be the possibility of a RSVP with a deadline as well. FB doesn\\\'t deliver that
column37: hence specialized web services for that or manually through email in many cases. FB also falls short when an event cost money and you have to pay in advance. Have a "confirmed" etc checkbox for the event organizers to check
column38: when needed.  Posting a poll and then posting an event is annoying and you lose interested people. Let it be possible to post an event with a few different times
column39: people check those that are possible for them and at a deadline the most common one is selected. After that people say if they are going.  A D* event should have an URL
column40: making it easy to publish on FB etc. That\\\'s another way to get more D* users. If it was a one click deal of joining D* via an existing FB etc account and you could publish your new event as a post with a link back on  etc
column41: that would bring more users to D*. "I\\\'ll have a house warming party
column43: or something like that. Users of FB click the link
column44: see a button to sign up&in with FB as well as the sign in page (unless already signed in) and after that click (and perhaps FBs authorization page) they see the posted event in all its glory
column45: that would bring in new users.\''

column10: b"b' The birth date fields in diaspora\\\\* are separated in day
column11: month and year. I guess if at least day and month are filled
column12: we are able to determine if today is the birthday of a user.So I propose the following spec: each new day
column13: for each user we check if today == dob. If so
column14: we add a new notification in the notification dropdown for each user who has this user in at least one aspect. If the notification sends or not an email can be set as for all other notifications in the setting panel.'"

column10: b'b" Hi
column11: We are working on the issue and have few questions: 1. We are using the object in order to send notifications to the birthday person contacts. The have and attributes and we need some clarifications about them. We are a bit unsure if receiving means that the user is receiving from the person or if it\'s the other way around. Specifically
column12: when we test the worker for this notification
column13: we want to test the case where the birthday person is not  with a contact. Which of these attributes should we set to false in the test? Should we test both? You can see the code here: url  lines 42 and 49. Accordingly
column14: we would need to change the condition in the worker url  line 14). 2. In the worker we are iterating over all the profiles that are in a pod in order to check their birthday. We were wondering if it would be more efficient to add an index for the birthday
column15: what do you think? 3. We added to the  page a checkbox to enable the user not to get birthday notification emails. From what we have searched
column16: it seems like this functionality is tested for all email types together. Is this true or should we test this functionality specifically for birthday notification emails? Thanks!"'

column10: b'b"  Yes
column11: contacts are a bit confusing. means
column12: that the reads posts of the (and shares with the  ). And means
column13: that the shares with the (so the other direction).  For the birthday notifications
column14: you need to check that both are true
column15: the person whose birthday it is
column16: needs to be with the user and the user needs to be (being interested in) the persons birthday.  By the way
column17: you can directly query the contacts from the database with these flags (in [check_]url  so you only have the contacts you want for your loop
column18: then you don\'t need the in the loop: I just checked that with my production database
column19: and with 87598 profiles the query needed 0.2091 seconds with mysql
column20: and I think that\'s OK for once per day.  But there is another problem with your query: only works with postgres
column21: so you need a different solution for mysql
column22: I used and for my test. You can see if the post runs with postgres with  . I think you are talking about these tests?  url This generates a test for each email type. So they are already tested each individually. All you need to do is to add your notification type here
column23: then it will be tested automatically:  url "'

column10: b'b"  Please could you also add an opt-out that Bob can set to prevent notifications being sent to his contacts on his birthday? So there are two opt-outs: 1. Don\'t send birthday notifications to my contacts; 2. Don\'t receive birthday notifications from my contacts."'
b'b" @goobertron that change would need federation changes. And we would need to first add this change then
column11: and wait so people can set that option and then in half a year we can add the notifications for birthday.  But I don\'t think that this is needed
column12: because when people don\'t want that others know when their birthday is
column13: they can simply not set it (it\'s optional)
column14: and then no notifications will be sent. That doesn\'t need any changes. When you publish your birthday
column15: people can also add it manually to their calendar and set a reminder for it
column16: so they receive notifications for it
column17: and you can\'t prevent them from adding the date to the calendar."'

column12: or to do something similar to the Comment key
column13: where there are three Notification types in the hash.  What do you think is a better solution? And how can we implement it the code? '"

column10: b'b\' Here are my thoughts on the **_**_ issue: If you\\\'ll indulge me while I get a little philosophical. ;) First
column11: as I\\\'ve said in several other threads and contexts
column12: I am totally against censorship
column13: but unfortunately
column14: this "freedom" also necessarily means that some nefarious types are going to abuse it by abusing others\\xe2\\x80\\x94Several people close to me (myself included) have experienced this abuse
column15: and it really messes with our ability to enjoy this community. This "freedom" (which I advocate) also means that there are few repercussions or consequences for those who choose to be abusive  threatening. I do not like the idea of podmins being moderators and watching  "Big Brother"-style
column16: in order to "protect the innocent." They should not be moral gatekeepers. It\\\'s tough enough just keeping the pods running (can I get a whut whut
column17: @Pistos?? ;) ) Having said that
column18: each of us should be empowered with tools to _protect ourselves_ online. So
column19: if Johnny Troll tells me that he\\\'d happily put a bullet in my head
column20: because he thinks the world would be better off without me
column21: well
column22: I would like the ability to **never ever** hear from him again. I don\\\'t really care if some of his ideas and posts are actually fairly insightful. Now
column23: I don\\\'t necessarily want to  Johnny Troll
column24: but I want to be able to lock him out of my (virtual) house
column25: and not worry about him  me again. This is not censorship. This is not crowdsourcing (which could be abused). This is me taking control of my little corner of D*. People should have every right to express themselves
column26: even be assholes online if that\\\'s their flavour. I don\\\'t really care. But
column27: I should be empowered to not have to deal with them. So here are my suggestions: First
column28: several levels of **_IGNORE**_:Already implemented is the "Ignore Johnny Troll" and the "Hide and mute post" options
column29: which are a good start. I would like to see it go a step further
column30: where Johnny Troll\\\'s comments are flagged and _"censored"_
column31: #nsfw style for **_me**_ (though visible for anyone who has _not_ "ignored" them). So
column32: if Johnny Troll has posted a comment on Jenny Friend\\\'s (who is a friend of mine) post
column36: with a note saying "You have chosen to ignore Johnny Troll\\\'s posts and comments. **Click here** if you would like to see this comment." **_BLOCK**_ \\xe2\\x80\\x94 Again
column38: but here\\\'s how I envision an effective "block" function. If I get a threat or harassment from Johnny Troll
column42: if he tries to comment on one of my posts
column44: You cannot comment on this user\\\'s posts." Or something to that effect. Once I block someone, they are added to a list of **Blocked Users** on my settings page, any of whom can be _unblocked_ by me at any time. If "Johnny Troll" is really Johnny Curmudgeon, and there was just a misunderstanding, then JC can send a note to the podmin explaining the situation, and the podmin can contact the me, and I can then decide to unblock JC.Similarly, if Johnny Troll has seen the error of his ways, and wants to change, then, being a believer in forgiveness, I think JT should have the opportunity to try to reconnect\\xe2\\x80\\x94via the podmin route, as stated before. But in both cases, I have full control over how JT can interact with me. Two things need to be absolutely sacrosanct at D*1) People should feel _safe_ here.2) Trollish behaviour should not be without its consequences*And as stated before, _consequences_ does not mean some kind of podmin-originated banishment, nor crowd-sourced "punishment
column46: the trollee should be empowered to not have to interact with the troll.\''

column10: b'b" Right now if I understand ignore correctly
column11: ignoring someone means you won\'t see them in your stream. You won\'t see their content
column12: or their comments
column13: when you\'re logged in. If that\'s not the case please file a bug with the specifics. However
column14: the ignored user can still interact with your content
column15: and that\'s not something we can change easily
column16: because of federation. Let\'s say
column17: for example
column18: you\'re on Pod A and you ignore Jane Smith who\'s on Pod B. That ignore is only recorded on Pod A Pod B has no idea about it. Then
column19: you post something public. It will get federated to Pod B because there are other users on that pod (who you have not ignored) who are following you. This means that the post will show up in Jane Smith\'s feed
column20: if it has tags that she follows
column21: and she\'ll be able to comment on it. However
column22: when Pod B notifies your pod that there\'s a comment from Jane Smith
column23: your pod will drop it because you\'re ignoring her
column24: so that comment won\'t appear anywhere except Pod B. The nature of a distributed system is such that you have full control over what **you** see
column25: but you have less control over what **other people** see. If this were a centralized network
column26: it would be easier to implement features that affect what other people do."'

diaspora	1734	closed	41	sarahmei	2011-08-05 09:22:53	1274.93	+1			b'b" Pod admins may modify and augment the code they run on their pod. Most of the larger nonpods run modified code that isn\'t in the main codebase. To date, most of those modifications have been cosmetic, or adding minor features. However, in theory, a pod admin could make whatever changes they wanted. When you befriend someone on a remote pod, you are placing a certain amount of trust in their pod admin. That pod admin has access to all the data you send your friend. That pod admin may also be running different code from what\'s on your pod. In addition, their terms of service may allow them to treat your data differently than it is treated on your pod. We\'re working on better messaging around remote pods\' terms of service, so that when you are considering following someone on a remote pod, you can tell what their ToS allows them to do. All of this is important because once data leaves your pod, your options for changing it are limited. That\'s the nature of a distributed system. You\'re giving up the downsides of a centralized system: single point of failure, monolithic one-size-fits-all experience, and user-unfavorable policies. In return you get a robust system that\'s hard to kill, where the user experience can be customized to fit what you want, and where you can make informed choices about the policies you feel comfortable with. But you also take on the downsides of a distributed system: inconsistent user experience, less control over data once it leaves your node, and a spectrum of policies around data management to keep track of. As I said, we\'re still working on surfacing all the relevant information to the user in a way that is intuitive, in the right place, and makes sense. But that\'s what we\'re working towards. There\'s always the possibility that a hostile pod enters the ecosystem, or, more likely, that a pod with lax security is compromised and goes from being a white hat, so to speak, to being a black hat. That\'s a problem in centralized systems as well, and in those cases, generally, the attacker has access to the entire dataset. At least with a distributed system, a compromised pod only has access to a fraction of the total network. "'
diaspora	1734	closed	42	madamephilosophe	2011-08-05 09:22:53	1396.9		+1		b'b\' Thanks again... But I\\\'m not sure from your reply how my questions are answered. So I will reflect back to you what I think you are saying and how it lines up with my questions.You seem to say (to me) that yes, as a whole once the message is published (by hitting the "share" button) the controls that have been selected by aspecting, direct how that post is handled by the decentralized system. What I imagined from what you depicted were different communication tubes, \\xc3\\xa1 la that scene in Sam Lowry\\\'s office in the movie Brazil.  :)  When you say that options are limited once it leaves my pod, what are my options? As far as I can tell from my experience on D\\\\* is that I can delete the post entirely (whether public or private).  That delete function seems to work like this:If I am the author of a post, I can delete any comments made to it, whether mine or someone else\\\'s (aside: however as Max indicates above, there is a bug right now that prevents anyone from deleting comments at all to one\\\'s own post). If I am not the author and I comment on another\\\'s post, I can only delete my own comments.  That seems to describe the basics of altering the original profile of a post. Is that fair to say? Is that comprehensive or are there caveats to that? Outside of that, what other options do I have? Off the top, it seems I can add people to aspects who would then be able to see the post at my profile page (not their stream) if they were not in my aspect crowd when I made the post. Is there anything else we should know?From your reply, it seems you are saying that it is possible for people to carve the code as they like for one\\\'s own pod. Essentially that is the lifeblood of open source software, so arguing that point of "all code should be the same" is really a fruitless one. But in terms of software design, I am not asking if it is possible to carve the code, but how difficult is it to bastardize the system that someone, who is on a pod that is not compliant with a privacy-safe rendering of the codebase, whom I\\\'ve unknowlingly or unwittingly shared with and who can then siphon my private post and corrupt its settings from being an aspected to a public one? I understand also that one of the things you to be saying is that you recognize there is need for some kind of evaluation system that is socially distributed, by providing a rubric to "objectively" evaluate the technical safety of a pod, as well as the reputation of a pod. But I also hear you saying there also needs to be a handshaking system among pods that allows pods to recognize good pods (or safe pods) from bad ones (or unsafe ones). So I am differentiating the social aspect from the technical one. I do understand there are pros and cons to a centralized vs de-centralized system. And I think it behooves anyone who moves off FB or Twitter to understand what they are doing by moving off D*.  Don\\\'t get me wrong. I am not proFB or any other Big Brother Social Network. But as it stands now, hypothetically anyway, my data on FB even though it is getting siphoned off by third party apps, and marketing creeps, is still housed in FB servers (as far as I know), and if there was a problem (that was a breach of their own TOS) I could sue FB for that breach and they would (I suppose) have to scrub their servers of the offending use of my data. Whether that is likely, is another discussion. But if a similar breech occurred on a D\\\\* network, anything off my pod is open shooting for anyone and I would have no recourse, because I would have to contend not only with ONE entity (as in the case of FB) but with as many entities as there are pods on the network. Right? So it means then if I am very concerned with this happening I should NEVER make a pubic post. In commenting upon something you said, I do not think it is possible to say that I as a user can customize my D\\\\* experience, because I cannot make public posts without a great risk. From what you say, there is no way to control my experience if I make public posts. So I would ask D\\\\* to reflect upon that and perhaps create more precise language about that.  For example, as far as informed decisions, I respectfully must disagree with you, because I was not aware that public posts meant public across the entire Internet, I did not know that my public posts were subject to SE indexing. I thought they were only public across the D\\\\* network. (I mean, I understand that NOW, but it was only a few weeks ago that I started to understand what happens when I make a public post, or even when I participate on someone else\\\'s public post). And I am still feeling uninformed as to whether if I delete a public post what the consequences are of doing that in the system.  To be fair, I understand that I am participating in an experiment, but I think that alpha users for being alpha users, should be given a fair shake, so that we can be some what assured we are not jeopardizing our online well-being by attempting to make a contribution to a larger good. If alpha users are treated with less care than airplane test pilots, no one except the most stupid users will participate. I include myself as a possible stupid user. I am hoping sincerely that I will not pay a price by contributing to the D\\\\* cause. I thank you again for your time to read my and make your comments. As well as your future response, if you have one.\''
diaspora	1734	closed	43	sarahmei	2011-08-05 09:22:53	701.37		+1		b'b" Public means readable by the public. Good suggestion though to provide more messaging. We\'ll think about where the right place is to put that. Re: options after you create a post for modification, the only thing you can do is request that it be deleted. It may not be deleted by all the pods you send the request to. For example, if the pod is down, it won\'t get the request, and the post will still be there. We can fix that sort of thing with better timeouts and retrying and so forth. But other pods may just be running buggy code that fails to delete the post, or something like that. It is part of the nature of a distributed system to be inconsistent."'

column10: b'b\' I wish to weigh in on this issue.  Recently I have seen someone mention this issue and argue that diaspora developers have an obligation to accommodate people who want "safe spaces."  In case you are curious where I saw this discussion
column11: it was [here]url Sadly
column12: this discussion seemed to have most
column13: if not all
column14: commenters
column15: supporting censorship.  The lack of understanding here is also important to note
column16: where the poster claims: _"Blocking people allows for the creation of what each individual considers a safe space without this we are leaving the vulnerable to fend for themselves. Without this we set the stage for the creation of centrally managed safe spaces (as Twitter has recently advocated) which is completely in opposition to the philosophy of Diaspora."_  I want to go on the record
column17: as a diaspora user myself
column18: who is willing to reject the sort of fallacious nonsense as the above statement. First
column19: blocking people results in (if the person attempts to comment on your posts
column20: something like)  "You cannot comment on this user\\\'s posts."  Ignoring means you cannot see a person\\\'s posts or comments anywhere.  As I understand it
column21: if your posts are public
column22: you are conveying that information to the crowd.  Private posts are for a specific set of people. Public posts
column23: go public. The notion that blocking people allows for the creation of a "safe space" is incorrect.The notion that diaspora developers need to create "safe spaces" or to foster a condition where any individual can create what they consider "safe spaces" are incorrect.The notion that without this sort of censorship motive one would ultimately end up with "centrally managed safe spaces" is incorrect. I do imagine that for some people who find themselves being trolled incessantly and want a way to essentially disable this from happening
column24: one part of the solution could be to make all your posts private
column25: but admittedly this sounds like not the most ideal solution. One thing I do think needs fixing for sure is the "Ignore vs. Block
column26: what happened" as mentioned above by @unity100 ~ who said
column27: _"Im not able to block someone. Only option that exists in their profile is ignore.If Ignore option is actually block option
column28: then the interface is confusing in that regard"_ Personally
column29: I\\\'ve never wanted to Ignore or Block anyone because I see Diaspora as a place where people can be free and where this shouldn\\\'t be necessary
column30: even if I really don\\\'t agree with what I see
column31: I can learn from what people are expressing.  But what if someone was threatening me with violence
column33: this has never happened to me.)  So I looked around for a Block button
column34: but could only find an Ignore in my case.  Again
column35: perhaps this needs both an Ignore and Block as it seems the meaning of these two things is different
column36: thus there should be a different button for each one. Diaspora is intended to allow people more room to maneuver than centralized systems such as twitter and facebook.  There is zero obligation for any developer to create a system which will allow you to create your own "safe spaces" "safe spaces" being an idea which functions all too often in order to allow some people to suppress free speech
column38: and reasonable talk. Diaspora fosters the potential for free speech because of its distributed nature and the desire of the community to keep it truly free.  I\\\'d like to see that continued and not see it undermined. O.K.
column39: that\\\'s my two satoshis on the subject.\''

column10: b"b' @jpka Put simply
column11: preview changes the user interface only.  Editing posts requires a change to federation; the way diaspora ratifies changes between pods.  The latter is is a much more dangerous and complicated process
column12: more prone to error
column13: and could create a requirement on an external service
column14: such as a third-party arbitrator (just as a possible example).  Preview is an interim measure which
column15: while not solving all cases
column16: makes the system more amenable while we sort out the more complicated feature requests.'"

column10: b'b\' Pistos said
column11:
From what I know of what the devs have been discussing, the way edit is going to go down is: People will be allowed to edit any time, but a revision history will probably be implemented. One of the major things to deal with is federation of edits. But that\\\'s not a showstopper. This will come, in time."  This is excellent news. Thanks for letting us know Pistos. This is so very important. And this is the best way to allow people to truly own their data and still allow folks to see what changes were made and respond accordingly.\''
diaspora	1762	open	43	davux	2011-08-12 07:26:20	173.23		+1		b"b' We should make a difference between protocol and implementation here. Currently the only implementation of the Diaspora federation protocols (Salmon, XRD, Webfinger, etc.) is the original Diaspora code, but that might change in the future. So we need to define, at network level, how post updates are broadcasted. And at implementation level, A) how updates are sent, and B) how updates from other people are received, handled, formatted, etc. I think splitting the problem around these 3 criteria is necessary, and as a bonus it will make the debate a little bit smoother.'

just" give a clue how to intelligently render them by establishing a link between the post revisions. After having links, the frontend could merge the posts and their comments into one stream.Imagine post revision markers inserted between comments.Other way is to keep the relevant status update version floating above the comments. The changes can also be represented in a compact way by default and they could be toggled just like quoted text in Gmail. All the workarounds sound good (preview, timeout, until no comments, minor change detection) and they are compatible with the approach I just described.\''
diaspora	1762	open	45	h6w	2011-08-12 07:26:20	445.45	+1			b'b" @onetom.  I like your idea, but it\'s still not entirely in the presentation layer.  In order for your proposal to work we would have to have an identifier to link the messages together (which we have, but the use of which might break the sync process), but also a sequence to specify the order of messages in the history.  Both of these would have to be in the protocol and somehow still ensure uniqueness across pods. Then you have the issue of privacy.  Consider the situation where a user is removed from another user\'s aspect between revisions of a message, meaning that the recipient still has access to that message but only before a certain revision.  This means that the pod has to withhold all revisions after the change.  This situation becomes more complex, of course, if the user is subsequently re-added to that aspect, resulting in a period of revisions being withheld."'
diaspora	1762	open	46	sarahmei	2011-08-12 07:26:20	1175.1		+1		b"b' I updated the title to be more like our other feature requests.'

column10: b'b" I\'m all for post revisions.  Having editable posts is a must for any real-world social network. To have editable posts you have three major options:1. Users can edit their posts in place and no notice that the post was edited
column11: I think we can all agree that this is not optimal.2. Users can edit their posts and post is marked edited but there is no revision history. People are going to start wanting to see a revision history.3. Users can edit their posts and there is a revision history
column12: people can look at the history for comments that don\'t make sense but were probably created before the post was edited. I think it\'s important to realize that all three options will be wanted
column13: but because there is no silver bullet we should go with the most general option. There will be cases where a user creates an embarrassing post and edits it
column14: yet the revision history still contains the embarrassing post and will come and ask for the ability to delete old revisions. However
column15: I think that we can all agree that we need revisioned posts and that deleteing old revisions should be a different discussion."'

column10: b'b\' +1 for the ability to edit posts and comments. Revision history would be nice
column11: but IMHO a simple "last edit @timestamp" notice is good enough for me.\''

column10: b'b\' From a user perspective
column11: to address the issue of deceptive or malicious editing after the fact
column12: a version history of the post should work.  Comments can maintain a pointer to the version "replied" to
column13: preserving the original context. For control of own data and privacy issues
column14: the option of a delete that also removes the version history seems sufficient.  Strongly +1ing editable .\''

column10: b'b\' I really like the idea of linking replies
column11: likes
column12: etc
column13: to the relevant revision. That would be a nifty feature that I haven\\\'t seen anywhere else. BUT
column14: upon displaying a post like that
column15: it should have a prominent notice that says something like "This post has been updated. Click here to see the latest version." This is essential for legitimate edits (e.g. "EDIT: Oh wow
column16: I had my facts completely wrong
column17: and need to take back a big chunk of what I was saying"). \''

column10: b'b\' As I understand it: Editing is highly desired by users.  However
column11: it\\\'s also among the first perceived shortcomings they encounter
column12: and possibly would prioritize other remaining work more highly if they were aware of its existence. Editing raises the possibility that existing comments will be misinterpreted due to the change.  This "conversational context" problem does not seem insurmountable to me. There are technical challenges
column13: some significant especially with regard to federation.  I have not found a discussion of the actual technical barriers
column14: nor am I yet familiar enough with the code to understand it. But  I wonder if there is an 80% solution that addresses a good bit of the need to edit
column15: while staying on "this side" of the difficult or intractable technical hurdles?  For example:  if the issue is federation
column16: maybe a first step is to make a post editable if it has not yet been transmitted to another pod?\''

column10: b'b" a versioning system would be a violation of the tenet that users own their content -when something is changed
column11: it\'s up to them to disclose or not disclose the update."'

column10: b'b\' +1 from me as well. Editing is highly desirable. There is a reason why most other bulleting boards and social networks allow editing. The fear of some user exploiting this feature by putting your comment out of context is highly hypothetical. You cannot throw out 99% of the  just to rule out that 1% of worst case scenario. The way Facebook does it is quite optimal IMHO. There is a little "Edited" sign in the footer of each edited comment. When you click on it
column11: you see the content and  of previous versions. Summary:1) Editing content is a must have. It needs to include a "this post was edited at []" notice = identical to all bulletin boards.2) Versioning (like in Facebook) is nice to have. When it comes to : you should be able to edit those as well
column12: as long as there are no  yet. It just makes plain sense.\''

column10: b'b" I am a admin of a very busy board.  A lot of time there will be people being rude to one another.  We have experienced issues with people that would post really terrible things to another member and then go and remove it so the admins can\'t see it ... Because of this
column11: we only allow members 1 hour in which to edit their post.  That is all they can possibly need.  If they need any other changes
column12: they are welcome to contact one of the admins to edit their post for them.  It doesn\'t even happen very often because most people who decide to edit a post do it within that first hour.  Just a idea."'

column10: b'b" The few boards where I got that
column11: I found it quite frustrating. It seems to me that it is a freedom to be able to  a post as many times as I want
column12: and whenever I want to. There will always be jerks among people
column13: but I\'d rather not making rules that will prevent my freedom because of their tiny stupidity."'

column10: b'b" Think of a board as a business as most boards are paid for by a sponsor of some sort.  Businesses don\'t have to give you the freedom to come in and act the way you want. Especially if you want to change your post and thus make ANYONE that replied to your post waste their valuable time.  However
column11: you do have the freedom to not join the board.  Again
column12: if a member has a hour to make changes
column13: which usually means correct spelling mistakes
column14: or change their post to articulate what they were trying to say in their post
column15: that is freedom enough.  Read site rules before you join.  If you don\'t like them
column16: move on to another board.  :+1: "'

column10: b'b\' if it\\\'s that big an issue
column11: ban the troublemakers.On Jul 17
column13:
Administator" notifications@ wrote:\''
diaspora	1762	open	69	MightyCreak	2011-08-12 07:26:20	359.68			+1	b'b" I prefer a system where you can signal a person that doesn\'t respect the rules and the admin can choose to ban  or find a more diplomatic solution. This way, only the troublemaker will see limited freedom, not everyone. But in the end, the best would be to have the choice. But I\'d rather that the first solution would be less strict, not all the boards are made of trolls."'
diaspora	1762	open	70	Administator	2011-08-12 07:26:20	881.82	+1			b'b"  You would be very surprised how many trolls and spammers sign up on a site every single day. Sometimes you can catch them before they post. Sometimes you can\'t. The whole thing about changing posts is some members choose to post something and then totally change it after a multiple amount of members have responded. Once they changed it, nothing makes sense anymore. Some members do it to cause trouble or if they don\'t like the responses they are getting so instead of reporting the person they change the post. Then the thread might have to be removed because of that and if we remove posts that were directed at the members post who is no longer meaning the same thing, then the admins get bashed for deleting those posts because people take the time to think out their response and take time to type it all out. Is it fair to them to get their posts removed since they didn\'t do anything at all? NO. You need to see both sides of it. We have had people get mad at our site. Leave in a huff, only to come back saying they never realized how having site rules made so much sense and how they appreciated the site. And finally saw why things were the way they were. We have one of the best sites out there with thousands of people posting so rules are key to help keep people from fighting or causing trouble on the site. Or causing a lot more work for admins because they choose to take their post into a totally different direction. Admins are volunteers who work hard and put up with so much abuse."'
diaspora	1762	open	71	8spinach	2011-08-12 07:26:20	896.68		+1		b'b\' the responses being deleted is literally the only possible outcome whenposts can\\\'t be edited and can only be deleted. these arguments make zerosense. when a post comes up that is problematic, it\\\'s not necessary toinvolve an admin if the original poster can edit and chooses to do so -inthat case, it\\\'s problem solved. what are you even saying, honestly?On Jul 19, 2015 12:45 AM, "Administator" notifications@ wrote:\''
diaspora	1762	open	72	Administator	2011-08-12 07:26:20	912.68			+1	b'b" The funny thing is, I edited my previous post like 5 times (all within about 20 minutes).. I ended up editing it back to what you quoted.. LOL  Because actually, you wouldn\'t have read my changes. Although any change I made wouldn\'t have made a difference.  I will just put them on this post.  On a different board with a ton of responses (not this one because there are very few responses here a day) it can become problematic because a member can change what they said.  Add to what they said.  etc. It doesn\'t solve anything to just let people edit their posts if it is making the other members responses not make any sense if you are reading it.  Unless the one responding quotes the original post.  Unfortunately not many people know how or use the quote button.  If only they did.  If we delete the RESPONSES as YOU say, then the person that took their time to post that response wasted their time.  is that at all FAIR??  If you think so, then when a bunch of your posts are removed, lets see if it irritates you because I will tell you, it will.  All because someone decides not to leave their post alone and change what they said or meant.  Its the original poster that is the problem, not the people responding to them. Like I said, if you don\'t like the site rules, that a site shows you BEFORE you click the join button then back the heck out and go on to another site. Go to a un-moderated site and see how rude some people can be to each other without any intervention by admins.  See how confusing a thread can get when people keep posting, then editing their post after about 20 people have responded to the post.  If you don\'t understand what I am trying to say.  Set up a board, get nearly 100,000 people posting on it without any rules.  Let them post as they like and see how long it takes you to start to HAVE to implement rules.  You\'ll understand then. :)  "'
diaspora	1762	open	73	8spinach	2011-08-12 07:26:20	928.52		+1		b'b\' we\\\'re not talking about a site, though. we\\\'re talking about a protocol. asis, you can\\\'t use a single diaspora\\\\* pod, anywhere, under anyone\\\'s control,even your own, with the ability to edit posts.On Jul 19, 2015 1:16 AM, "Administator" notifications@ wrote:\''

So let\'s **not** continue this argumentation (or at least not here), because it\'s not really the place for long philosophical threads ;)"'

column11: but reading over the conversations dating back to 7 yrs ago (in a few different places) I think all the fretting about people going back and changing a comment or post in bad faith amounts to a user hostile attitude.  Most people will use the edit feature in good faith. The few that don\'t will lose engagement and trust. For the most part

column15: will I be able to publish a post

column17: I get comments asking for clarification will I be able to edit the post again to add an addendum to the bottom of the post clarifying the details of my narrative? 3. Will there be a time limit of minutes
column18: days
column19: weeks
column20: months for editing? 3. Will I be able to make similar edits to my comments on my or someone else\'s post? 4. Will there be the typical notation on the  that the  was (for example) 5. Will we be notified of every edit made on posts or comments we\'ve interacted with? 6. If I make a bunch of changes experimenting with the markdown to get the best presentation I can

I used to work as a technical writer so I\'m equipped to interface with technical people and translate it into end user."'

column10: b"b' Fix #1960: User menu inaccessible for people with low resolutions'"

b"b' Fixes Issue #1960. Header element is now shifted and resized any time the window is scrolled or resized. This has the added benefit of letting a user resize the window below 950px wide and still have full access to the entire header.'"
b"b' If this code should go somewhere else
column11: please let me know.'"

column10: b'b" I\'m not so sure about this.  We\'re sticking to a strict 960px grid right now.  Since our site\'s width isn\'t fluid
column11: I don\'t see why we would special case narrowing the header (content on the site would not be visible)."'

column10: b'b" Imo it\'d be the easiest way to replace the for .container in  with and maybe also position the #user_menu with float:right instead of absolute positioning."'
b'b" It\'s true that the site\'s width isn\'t fluid
column11: due to for in
column12: but the  \'s width is fluid (in ). Because the element has a fixed width and the element has a 100% width
column13: the element effectively has a equal to the width of the element. Coupled with the rule on the element
column14: the user menu becomes completely inaccessible for browser windows less wide than the width. Perhaps I wasn\'t clear enough in the description of #1960; un-maximize your browser window and scroll right
column15: paying close attention to the header area
column16: to see what I mean. This pull request really just uses a trick with positioning and give the appearance of the scrolling left to right with the rest of the page. The _visible_ width remains unaffected. If there is no left-right window scrolling
column17: then this fix is completely undetectable; the width of the element remains equal to what it would be at 100%. (If there were a way to make an element\'s position only on the y axis
column18: then I would have just done that instead.)"'

column10: b"b' Maybe replacing all fixed width properties with max-width. Would help generally with smaller screen sizes.'"
b'b" @cparker I really don\'t feel sure about using javascript for such a task."'
b'b" @untitaker that\'s not how  works.  we employ blueprint\'s 24-column grid system
column11: which goes off of pixels
column12: and assumes a that is a set size -overriding blueprint\'s declaration means everything breaks. if we were to make a fluid layout
column13: that\'s a larger undertaking
column14: and also means ditching blueprint\'s grid system. for now
column15: we don\'t want to do this. as a side note: the 960px width is optimized for all modern displays.  i don\'t think we need to make an exception for smaller resolutions (tablets and smartphones are smart and will scale the site accordingly
column16: even if they don\'t have 960px widths)."'

column10: b'b" 960px width is a site-width invented back then when -screens had **standardized resolutions**
column11: mostly because there were not much tablets. Now you can\'t rely on that anymore. And the zooming-feature of the touch-browsers is nothing you can rely on too
column12: because it\'s a **fallback** and not a feature designers  rely on."'

column10: b'b" sorry @cparker15
column11: i didn\'t notice your previous comment. dan hansen is the js master around here.  @ohaibbq -your thoughts on this one?"'

column10: b'b" I understand what you\'re saying
column11: @danielgrippi
column12: but the is unaffected by blueprint beyond having its minimum width effectively set by the of the  . As it stands now
column13: Diaspora is unusable for people stuck on 800x600 resolutions. (And it is odd-looking to see the stay put horizontally in an un-maximized window.) This pull request fixes that by making the user menu accessible by allowing it to scroll into view
column14: and it does so while being the least disruptive to any other styling or structure decisions already made for the UI. Just as the UI has more or less matured
column15: I think it would be much more of an undertaking than it\'s worth to fix this bug by doing lots of restructuring. Another option would be to remove the positioning on the and readjust the value any time the window is scrolled vertically. With no positioning
column16: the would be allowed to scroll horizontally with the rest of the page. Yet another option
column17: which removes the use of JavaScript
column18: would be to add a scrolling wrapper element immediately after the element
column19: and then this would be what scrolls instead of the window. A side effect of this would be that the element would no longer have a minimum width imposed by the element. However
column20: the having no minimum width at all could lead to its own set of problems."'

column10: b'b" can\'t we accomplish the same effect by using css instead of js?  how do twitter and Facebook accomplish this?  i\'m pretty sure they wouldn\'t use js..."'
b'b" With **Facebook**
column11: if I resize the window
column12: the element is no longer (from the class) to the top of the window; instead
column13: it reverts to positioning. This is done by  the class on the element—using JavaScript—specifically under the following conditions: (Do a search for _tinyViewport_ in the mess of Facebook\'s randomly-named minified JavaScript files; you\'ll eventually find where this is done using their method.) With **Twitter**
column14: the element\'s position is adjusted—with JavaScript—when the window is scrolled to the right. (Go to Twitter
column15: locate
column16: and search for _top-bar-inside_.) The header has a finite in
column17: so it doesn\'t run into the problem of having the background color only fill up to the width of the window (instead of the width of the document). Because the in Diaspora has a
column18: it only stretches as wide as the window
column19: so when the position is adjusted
column20: the background color of the scrolls away. This is why the adjustment is needed (what I tweaked in the most recent commit above)
column21: otherwise the user menu will be visibly floating outside of the element (due to the element\'s being  ). _(As I mentioned previously
column22: it\'s not possible to make an element on only one axis using a pure CSS solution; JavaScript is required to accomplish this effect.)_"'

column10: b"b' User should be able to opt-out of sending their posts in emails to other users'"
b'b" Currently
column11: if users have set to receive email notifications
column12: the full text of other users\' comments and posts are sent to them via email. This can be a privacy concern to some. It would be better if each user can choose whether or not  posts and comments are allowed to show up in other users\' emails."'

column10: b'b" I\'ve basically got the code to do this. Do I need to write an rspec or cucumber for it?"'
b'b" I think the convenience of being able to respond via email to an email notification is huge
column11: so we should retain the ability to do that.  An option that allows a user to keep his private messages out of the mailboxes of others could be possible.  You definitely need to test that thoroughly
column12: it\'s exactly the sort of thing that will be broken by future code.  It would also have to federate
column13: so it\'s not totally simple."'

column10: b'b" @fermionic: Where\'s your code?  I\'ll try to help you out with the specs or whatnot.  This is an important issue."'

b'b\' The code for my pod is at: url  The code specifically for hiding ones own text in email notifications involves modifications to the following files:   In summary: a new email_type of "silent" is added in user_. Each notification mailer class then creates an object "text_owner" that allows the view code to check if a "silent" email_type for the owner of the text exists. If it exists
column11: then an alternate message is displayed in the email. The notification mailer classes for comments also check if the owner of the post wants his text hidden
column12: if so
column13: the subject line of the email is replaced with alternate text. The following views were modified to check if the text owner has a "silent" email_type:   And the following was modified to allow the user to check a box to hide text in email notifications and update the database with a "silent" email_type:  Finally
column14: the text of the alternate messages for the email notifications are found in:  I believe this code works
column15: to the best of my ability to test (I don\\\'t currently have the ability to make sure it federates). The main thing that needs to be done is to write rspec tests for the different scenarios. I don\\\'t really know how to write rspec tests
column16: but I think that if someone could help write an example test for one scenario
column17: I could probably figure out how to do the rest.\''

column12: sorry. The branch is fermionicdiaspora-deployed'"

b'b" I wish I knew what to tell you fermionic
column11: or that someone who does would.  I appreciate you coders out there working on Diaspora.  I\'m anxious to see this feature implemented so I can be more candid with what I write in instant messages and also in comments on restricted posts"'

column10: b'b" As I posted in #2271
column11: this is very technically difficult at the moment because user preferences don\'t federate. So if you opt-out
column12: you prevent your own pod from including your text in emails
column13: but other pods will still include it in emails they send. Each pod sends email for its own users
column14: so when you comment on something
column15: email is being sent individually by every pod who has a user who should be notified. In that case
column16: if you opt-out
column17: users on your pod will get the empty email. All the other users will get the full text. Let\'s revisit this once we\'ve had a chance to think about federating user prefs."'

column12: to see a "mockup" picture of the proposed features) sarahmei
column13: hopefully you might reconsider the merit of this feature
column14: with this alternative approach.\''

column10: b'b" What\'s the deal with SSL and specifically StartSSL?"'
b'b\' First of all
column11: thanks for your work on the project. It seems Diaspora definitely does not support self-signed SSL certificates
column12: but the free provider recommended in the documentation (StartSSL) [has been recently compromised]url  and as of June 2011
column13: _"The fifth certificate authority to be hacked this year
column14: StartSSL has suspended issuing its free SSL certificates indefinitely."_ At a minimum
column15: I\\\'d recommend removing the reference to using StartSSL from the docs as soon as possible
column16: and instead recommend [CAcert]url  provided that Diaspora works with their certs. (not sure on this as I saw an issue that seemed to state that CAcerts were not working with Disapora) To my knowledge
column17: CAcert has not been compromised and at least is as trustworthy as SSL can be considered trustworthy these days.\''

column10: b"b' thanks for the comment.  care to update this wiki? :D'"
b'b" StartSSL has been hacked
column11: but the hackers weren\'t able to issue certificates. You can get a free certificate again. The advantage of StartSSL is that it is still trusted by browsers
column12: CACert isn\'t. So I would suggest both."'

column10: b'b\' Currently for me
column11: StartSSL is a non-starter. Aside from the implications from being hacked (considering SSL is pretty much fundamentally worthless anyway) the site is broken and gives this error each time I attempt to use Firefox to sign up for a cert: Further
column12: it actually crashes Safari when I attempt to use its control  a StartSSL cert in that browser. I realize this is not Diaspora\\\'s problem directly
column13: but it is a huge blocker that will prohibit the average hobbyist who is curious about Diaspora from getting their own pod going and connecting it to others. I asked the _question_ "what\\\'s the deal?" here in order to get at some answers which I don\\\'t have. Hence
column14: @maxwell
column15: I am not going to update the wiki unless I have a clear answer to the "what do I do for an SSL cert?" question. I have managed to get my own pod up and running
column16: but I am using a self-signed SSL certificate
column17: and while this works for intra-pod activity
column18: I\\\'m not going to be able to do any inter-pod communication from my understanding until I get a trusted cert. While @gladiac commented to include mentions of both StartSSL and CAcert in the wiki
column19: I cannot imagine how that would help anyone since a CAcert is as untrusted as a self-signed cert
column20: and StartSSL to be frank
column21: is a mess. So I guess the summary is: I need these questions answered before I can begin seriously participating:1. Does Diaspora support self-signed certificates?2. Should the project recommend these CAs who issues certs that may not fully work?3. Should the project recommend that those interested in setting up their own pod just buy a cert and if so
column22: **which** specific kind of cert is required? I really want this project to succeed
column23: and I am willing to put forth effort such as editing the wiki
column24: contributing code
column25: and more
column26: but I need a little guidance and understanding before I can do so. :)\''

column10: b'b" Oops
column11: didn\'t mean to close. :/"'

column10: b'b" a) If you\'re big enough then sooner or later you will get hacked in some way. This is something you have to accept (see ). b) StartSSL their key signing infrastructure has a good security design
column11: so the attacker wasn\'t able to create fake certificates. Their website got hacked and they fixed it. c) StartSSL is the only issuer which offers free certificates as far as I know. d) SSL is broken but it isn\'t worthless. If you think it is worthless why do you use it at all?"'

column10: b'b" OK
column11: I\'ve revisited the StartSSL situation from scratch
column12: and have a cert from them that appears to be working. I will await some feedback / ideas regarding -signed certs and update the wiki accordingly."'

column11: thanks.'"

column10: b"b' URL with special characters (e.g. umlauts) not parsed correctly'"

b"b' When using URLs with special characters like German umlauts in posts the resulting HTML link is wrong. There are two different cases whether you put an URL in markdown syntax like [text](URL) or a plain URL in a post. In the former case the characters before the last special character are treated as a one link and the remaining characters as another one. Both are wrong. In the latter case only the characters starting from the last special characters are interpreted as a link
column11: which of course is wrong.An example link could be the following: url \\xc3\\xbcndnis-f\\xc3\\xbcr-krankenh\\xc3\\xa4/'"

column10: b"b' can you include a link to a public post which has this problem for our records? Thanks!'"

b'b" User can\'t explicitly switch to the mobile version of the site from the desktop version"'
b"b' At present Diaspora implicitly decides what version of the site to load (mobile or desktop one)
column11: based on some user agent detection. This however fails completely for several mobile browsers
column12: for example for Mobile Firefox (Fennec) running on Harmattan. Since there are cases when mobile browser detection fails
column13: there should be an option to manually switch between mobile and desktop versions
column14: which will help such users.'"

column10: b"b' This link exists on the mobile site
column11: we should just put it in the layout'"

column10: b"b' Also I believe iPads should get the full version of the site by default
column11: not the mobile.'"

column10: b'b" It might be worthwhile in the long run to use CSS3 media queries
column11: which automatically resize and tweak the frontend to fit different screen sizes. By querying the screen size
column12: I think the site would allow itself to show the mobile frontend much more easily than trying to determine whether the browser is a mobile one or not. This could also be particularly useful as some devices like tablets occasionally do not have such a clear specification as to whether they\'re one or the other. Just food for thought."'

column10: b"b' For automatic adjustment it really should rely on some combination of physical size and screen resolution.'"
b'b" For this issue
column11: let\'s just add the mobile toggle to the main layout to allow explicit switching between the main site and the mobile site."'

column13: they figuratively had more money than God to create it and a vast pool of brilliant young-ish minds to dream it up. Yet still they had to coerce and sometimes
column14: as in the case of YouTube

column17: myself included

column19: my friends (lower case "F") tell me that they would be hard pressed to switch services simply because they are afraid that no one else will. column22: for that matter. I think that if they were to add an alternative to "Like" the problem would be this: people would use it. As it stands right now
column23: you can post anything you wish and the only purely quantitative feedback you will ever get
column24: aside from the number of comments
column25: is the number of "Likes". I have a feeling that if they were to add a "Dislike" feature that many would be seriously put off by people simply "Disliking" their posts. I don\\\'t know why but there is something about human psychology wherein much significance is placed on things with numbers attached to them much like scoring. Right now you can only get a positive "score"
column26: if you get anything at all. I would be willing to wager that if a "Dislike" feature were added

column28: it\\\'s always sunny in Facebook Land... I think a good alternative would be to have some sort of neutral indicator such as "Viewed". column10: b'b\' CybershamanX is absolutely correct here
column11: and I\\\'m a bit concerned that the Diaspora devs don\\\'t seem to realize how important this kind of functionality is in getting people to switch.  It is a DEAL-BREAKER that Facebook content be available to new users
column12: at least as an option
column13: regardless of what privacy issues this might raise.  The number 1 priority for participating in social media is to be connected
column14: and regardless of what fantastic ideals we might be pitching for joining a non-commercial decentralized one that doesn\\\'t spy on you or advertise.... it\\\'s plainly obvious that most people trade all of those things for the connectivity with just a little grumbling.  They go where the people are. Even speaking as someone who really believes 1000% in Diaspora\\\'s purpose and would love to see Facebook burn to the ground
column15: I am STILL reluctant to join because it severs so many of my connections.  I can proselytize to my friends until I\\\'m blue in the face
column16: but they won\\\'t switch for the same reason I hesitated
column17: only they DON\\\'T have a tin-foil hat like mine to motivate them.  For so many people
column18: myself included
column19: just keeping up on Facebook is enough work
column20: I don\\\'t need another news feed to read in a separate platform where nobody I know lives. I\\\'m reminded of the way Apple is slowly unseating the incumbant SMS protocol by providing a completely user-experience-transparent alternative (iMessage) that most people have no idea they\\\'re using.  When iOS devices message each other
column21: they use iMessage
column22: when they message other mobile devices they revert to SMS.  This switch is completely invisible to the user
column23: and it would not have taken hold if it had been otherwise.  Now they\\\'ve amassed such a user base using iMessage that it is practical
column24: even a selling point that Wifi-only devices and Macs can communicate via this protocol.  But if they had approached people 5 years ago and said "Hey
column25: wanna switch to iMessage? It\\\'s better in every way
column26: but you can\\\'t communicate with anyone who uses SMS"
column27: they would have been roundly rejected
column28: and rightfully so. That\\\'s the kind of connectivity we need.  Regardless of how it might clutter up the Stream or compromise privacy (only for correspondence via the FB protocol yeah?)
column29: it is absolutely essential and you will not see Diaspora unseat Facebook without it.  We could even be pushy in clever little ways
column30: like a little reminder at the bottom of FB correspondence that warns of an insecure connection
column31: or some other "bad network" "good network" highlighting.  Privacy will come gradually instead of a complete detachment from one\\\'s less progress-minded peers.\''

column10: b'b" The libv8 and therubyracer gems aren\'t included in the Gemfile by default because they can cause problems on some hosting environments (especially Heroku) and they\'re pretty big dependencies that really aren\'t needed in most cases. On OSX or Windows (does anyone really do Rails development on Windows? :grin:) there\'s already an execjs compatible Javascript runtime built into the OS. In most Linux distributions
column11: it isn\'t usually installed by default but  is compatible with execjs and is usually easy to install. The execjs gem is already included
column12: since it\'s a dependency for uglifier. It just needs a compatible javascript runtime.  I guess this explains why didn\'t work for @andrejpodzimek though
column13: a javascript runtime.. whether the OSX or Windows built-in runtime
column15: therubyracer or (for JRuby) therubyrhino.. is a requirement for the Rails 3.1 asset pipeline."'
