column13: doing it each time before deploying to heroku
column14: or upload to some CDN.  So the point is
column15: maybe those 3 gems should go inside the ASSETS group
column16: so that heroku does not even need to install them.  In mac OS X
column17: you are only needed to install Xcode and Xcode Command Line Tools (it needs gcc) I don\'t remember if you need nodejs if you already have java and gcc on the box (for Linux and OSX) and forget about windows :D LOL "'

column10: b"b' so to sum up
column11: new diaspora with rails 3.1 assets will need: 1. GCC: anyone doing rails development will have it anyway. (osx: xcode and : build-essentials)2. JAVA: already in OSX
column12: need to install on linux. (easy)3. ? can anyone confirm? ( brew install node)4. anything im missing? '"

column10: b'b" It\'s possible they might support them now
column11: it\'s been quite a while since I\'ve tried to use them (bamboo stack at the time) but I know there were a lot of known issues and even a special version of therubyracer just for Heroku. Heroku (cedar stack) does precompile assets during slug compilation on every push
column12: so if we add them to the assets group Heroku would still install them. These are big gems too
column13: we\'d be installing the whole V8 library to do what  already does for us on Heroku cedar. I don\'t remember what the slug size limit is
column14: but mine is already up to 50mb
column15: and the larger your slug is the longer it takes to start your app on every deploy (or to start a new dyno if you scale up). Windows has its own issues as far as Rails development goes.. I won\'t even try it lol.. but it does have a compatible Javascript engine built in (Windows Script Host). OSX also has one built in (JavaScriptCore). The only time you should ever need TheRubyRacer is if you\'re deploying to a system where  isn\'t installed."'

column10: b'b" GCC is needed
column11: we have some gems that have C extensions Java shouldn\'t be needed with the asset pipeline
column12: but it was needed for Jammit when we were on 3.0 so most podmins will probably already have it installed anyway.  is needed under Linux (sudo apt-get install nodejs)
column13: but it\'s optional on OSX since JavaScriptCore is compatible. edit: The only extra dependency should be  for Linux (like I said
column14: OSX is compatible already)
column15: see [execjs]url  and the [Rails Asset Pipeline Guide]url "'

column10: b"b' ok
column11: cool. I guess you are right about the bamboo stack. I also havent used heroku for a while. but I checked my Gemfile for the heroku app and those gems are inside the Assets group. btw
column12: the limit is 100MB
column13: if you use gems from git in your Gemfile it will make the stack grow very quick.  so
column14: the final question: should the precompiled assets be added to git by diaspora devs or should the pod admins be required to run rake assets precompile on their own? '"

column10: b'b" With Heroku or Capistrano
column11: rake assets:precompile should be called for you automatically on every deploy so it\'s probably best not to include those generated files in the repo.. but I will have to fire up VirtualBox pretty soon and try a Cap deploy to a VM just to be sure
column12: I know the recipe is included in the Capfile. :grin: While it is a big dependency and I don\'t think most people should need it
column13: there probably should be a comment in the assets section of the Gemfile (like the one in a freshly generated Rails 3.1 or 3.2 app) to let people know they can use that gem if they need to and point them to more information."'

column10: b"b' yes
column11: sounds good. my  note that when deploying with capistrano to EC2 small or micro
column12: running the rake assets:precompile task can take a long time
column13: maybe even 5-10 minutes (20 minutes on ec2 micro). '"

column10: b'b" 20 minutes? I guess I should stop complaining about how long my machine takes to run assets:precompile :
column11: but I guess there are certain use-cases where it makes sense to run assets:precompile locally and deploy those files to the server too. In that case
column12: you can always precompile the assets and then to add them to your repo even though they\'re in .gigitnore Definitely something to keep in mind as the documentation is being worked on
column13: I don\'t know that I\'d ever deploy to an EC2 micro (not when Heroku is so simple and.. for my purposes anyway.. free)
column14: but I\'m sure it\'s not too uncommon."'

column10: b"b' yep
column11: it takes very long time
column12: EC2 cpu is very much limited. An ec2 micro can run rails fine (pg + 1 rails + 1 resque worker)
column13: the only problem is booting rails which takes a long time. Besides ec2 is availble in regions where it might be more convinient than heroku (US only) if you need help woking out docs or deployment strategies
column14: I can help. (diaspora podmin for 18 months) :D  cheers'"

column10: b'b" True
column11: EC2 could be more convenient in some situations
column12: especially for podmins outside the US.. and a micro is also free for a year unless (like me) you\'ve had your EC2 account since before they introduce the free tier. There\'s some discussion of documentation cleanup on the diaspora-dev google group
column13: any  related docs are on the wiki here at github. I\'m sure at least a few probably need to be updated to reflect some of the recent changes (especially the asset pipeline).. and I\'m going to walk a friend through deploying a pod to Heroku soon so I\'ll be updating and cleaning up the Heroku guide."'

column10: b"b' I have just pulled the latest release onto my pod and I am seeing this issue.  I have always used my email address to login.  I have just had to ssh into the server and retrieve my username from the database(!). Is there anyway to turn this off or am I going to have email each one of my users their username?'"
b'b" If your users know their Diaspora ID (name@) they should already know their username.. it\'s everything before the @. As @nunski said
column11: the Diaspora ID shows by default every time you log in
column12: so at least in theory most of your users should know their ID. username vs. email address as the login credential is also a slight security optimization. Allowing login with an email address means that if I know your email address
column13: I (as an outside hacker
column14: not knowing your Diaspora ID amd not having an account on any pod) have half of what I need to brute-force my way into your account. If you\'re using a username that isn\'t necessarily related to your email address
column15: I would have to know your Diaspora ID (meaning that someone
column16: somewhere
column17: would have my IP address and email address logged.. and possibly even my Facebok and Twitter.. because obviously I have an account) to attempt a brute-force attack."'

column10: b'b\' I\\\'m running both a private Diaspora pod and a private Friendica server. From examining the logs of both
column11: I\\\'ve noticed the following:Most of the lost comments are due to signature validation errors. However
column12: it\\\'s hard to pin down a consistent cause of the errors. On my servers
column13: every person has some comments get through
column14: and most people have some get lost. Some people seem to lose almost all (but not all) of their comments. Others lose only one or two. As far as I can tell
column15: either there\\\'s something subtle about the text of some comments that causing the signatures to fail for those comments
column16: or there\\\'s something wrong with the public keys that are being sent. I have seen one public key get sent from Diaspora to Friendica with a missing character in the middle.I\\\'ve also seen comments that Diaspora receives to relay to contacts on a post get lost with a random "received a comment but no corresponding post" error. The weird part is
column17: Diaspora will sometimes relay to one contact without any problem
column18: but then produce the above error for another contact.\''

column10: b'b" that\'s really interesting
column11: so diaspora doesn\'t send the keys correctly?"'

column10: b'b" I can\'t come to any conclusions yet about exactly where the breakdown is happening. It could be that Friendica is dropping something while it decodes the encrypted salmon
column11: for example (I\'m not saying that\'s what\'s happening either
column12: just saying that until the string has been carefully traced out the blame can\'t be placed anywhere). I\'ve only seen it once for sure
column13: but basically what I saw was that a comment sent by Diaspora was rejected by Friendica based on signature validation problems. The public key that was sent with the comment was off by one character in the middle of the key from the public keys both in Diaspora\'s database and Friendica\'s database. I also need to take some time to understand which public key Diaspora uses to verify the signature. As far as I can tell
column14: there are three possible sources to get the public key from: 1) Diaspora\'s local database
column15: 2) a webfinger request to the remote user
column16: or 3) the public key included in the sent message. It shouldn\'t be too hard to figure out
column17: but I\'m at work and don\'t have time at the moment to dig into it."'

column10: b'b" @hfase01 I haven\'t paid very close attention to Resque errors
column11: but when I did look I never saw one related to federation problems. I see the problems in the log file
column12: as either or (essentially)  . The is another problem
column13: separate from the whitespace issue that I\'ve found. @Raven24 I don\'t see any reason to transfer the whitespace verbatim
column14: we just need to remove the whitespace before creating a signature. @maxwell I\'m seeing the problems when not in single process mode. Further
column15: I can reproduce the problem on
column16: which I\'m sure is not in single process mode. The bug appears to be very simple to me. If a user enters whitespace before the text of her comment
column17: then when the comment is created (through
column18: which calls
column19: which then calls
column20: which itself calls  ) the signature is created using the text that has the leading whitespace. But then
column21: when the comment is relayed off to another pod
column22: the leading whitespace is stripped out when the XML is created. Then
column23: when the next pod gets the comment
column24: it checks the signature using the text with the leading whitespace stripped out and the signature fails verification. That causes the comment to disappear. So it seems like the fix is simple: just strip out the leading and trailing whitespace in the comment text before creating the signatures. The only problem I\'m having is that I can\'t get the RSpec test I wrote to fail so that I can submit the fix. I believe that my inability to get the test to fail has more to do with my inexperience with RSpec than the idea that there\'s no problem
column25: because I can consistently reproduce the problem on live pods."'

column10: b'b" Ok
column11: I figured out the RSpec problem. There were two things I was doing wrong
column12: in the following lines: First
column13: the function is not the main function used to create a comment. That is done with the function. The latter function saves the comment to the database
column14: and a is done on the text before saving to the database. By using the function
column15: the test was never stripping the text
column16: so the verification upon receiving the XML didn\'t fail. Second
column17: even if was changed to
column18: the test would still not work
column19: because after the signatures were created by either or
column20: I was then re-assigning explicitly
column21: which then used the stripped text. That also made the upon receiving the XML not fail. I\'ve submitted another commit that contains a working RSpec test and the fix suggested by @maxwell "'

column13: but because the design is bad. And what\\xe2\\x80\\x99s the use of it in this case? It would pile another point of confusion to alleviate the one we are discussing right now. If \\xc2\\xbba way to escape that page\\xc2\\xab is what is needed
column14: then that should be the logo in the top left
column15: linked to the front page. But not something which obstructs the normal sign up flow.'"

column10: b'b" I do agree with @jancborchardt on this that instead of a cancel button maybe just a logo in a nice header to the pod front page. But of course the same issue stands we do not have code for that yet. IMHO the whole sign up page is broken because there is no link to the main page. Making people edit urls if they decide not to sign up just yet is not acceptable. So IMHO if this patch looks ok and works personally don\'t see issues with merging it and then maybe changing it later. A link out of the sign up page would just make much more sense than cancel (since there isn\'t anything to cancel yet the user hasn\'t really done anything to cancel)."'
b'b" I\'ve added a [thread on loomio]url  for us to have a further discussion on this
column11: if necessary. If it comes down to it
column12: we can even put it to a vote. Personally
column13: I think having a button to clear all the fields on a page that you were going to leave anyway is a bit overkill
column14: but I don\'t feel too strongly about it any which way. I think just having a home link on user registration is a good compromise

column11: closing this is better than merging. A cancel button is a really butchered solution to this problem and will introduce more problems by people misclicking
column12: then thinking \\xc2\\xbbwtf\\xc2\\xab and then just not signing up for Diaspora.'"

column10: b"b' Please also see this article about it: url  and keep in mind: Rarely any popular web service (I couldn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t find any) has a cancel button on their sign in or sign up.'"
b"b' Accordingly url  +1 for merge. I pledge to make a proposal as spoken [here]url '"

b"b' Can we stop splitting the problem solution to this \\xc2\\xbbdiscussion\\xc2\\xab platform? It\\xe2\\x80\\x99s not optimal to design based on a democratic discussion process where everyone just +1s and side for an \\xc2\\xbbopinion\\xc2\\xab
column11: ignoring research and general practice in interface and interaction design. Adding a cancel button is a worse solution than we have currently
column12: and putting that in until someone puts in a linked header is inferior to just not doing it and waiting for the header. People will accidentally cancel and they will be pissed off.'"

column10: b"b' I mean
column11: I can also get a bunch of people to +1 me. The decision is currently being made based on the amount of people who agree. This is not a good way to do it especially in a community (as normal in open source) which is mainly composed of developers and less of people with design & usability experience.'"

column10: b'b" Hey @jancborchardt  it\'s community rules. If majority wants you can\'t keep saying research and general practise. Or you can but the majority will still win.  proposal on  if needed? Deadline something short
column11: week or something...?"'

column10: b"b' @jancborchardt that is also true
column11: but we do not have any designated group for design decisions yet. Until we have that (like the Github group now who are responsible for the actual source maintenance) we have to go by majority. '"

column10: b'b" Honestly; I see a lot of where Jan is coming from. While  is excellent for discussions for getting on the same page
column11: it\'s not purely intended to be a majority-rule platform for every action an organization makes. That can quickly descend into conversational chaos. We used it that way to put some important pieces in place
column12: and community devs are on the same page about a lot of things now
column13: but I feel that having a  phase for something as small a feature as this may be overkill. Look how long it\'s already been sitting here. Conversely; if Jan would like to make a counter-proposal
column14: or vote no on this proposal with the reasons he\'s stated
column15: there\'s no reason why other people wouldn\'t agree with him. He\'s made a good point about it. Life\'s too short to sweat the small stuff. If we must do a proposal for something this small
column16: let\'s have a voting phase for less than 5 days. Otherwise
column17: let\'s close this an do the suggested fix. Sent from my Homing Pigeon."'

column10: b"b' Delete posts from wordpress when original post has been deleted'"

b'b" I recently wrote code that removes (aka: hides =P) posts from Facebook when they are deleted from D\\\\* (Issue #3939). I would like to extend this functionality to the rest of the services that we integrate with.  I\'m hoping I can get some technical input from the community on how best to handle the Post to Service relationship before I start. For the Facebook fix
column11: I had added a new column to the post table that keeps track of the facebook_id of the post. I\'m guessing we will need to keep track of separate id\'s for each service that a post goes out to. Is there a  efficient way to keep track of these without having to add a new column to the table for each service?##   Want to back this issue? **[Post a bounty on it!]url  We accept bounties via [Bountysource]url  "'

column10: b"b' Hm
column11: we could introduce a ServicePost model that belongs to a post and a service and use that to keep track to which services a post got shared to and have a remote_id column or whatever on that. On the other hand when doing that
column12: the idea to display that information in the stream comes up quickly and introducing yet another table to the stream generation feels equally bad as adding a few more columns to the posts table.'"

column10: b'b" We could store all of them as a serialized object in a single \'remote_ids\' column in the posts table. Would eliminate the need to add a new table and would minimize the number of columns we\'d have to add to the posts table. The trade-off would be that we would lose the ability to  by remote_id
column11: but I can\'t think of many reasons we\'d need to do that. Maybe if we wanted to add like a \'Show me everything I\'ve shared with X service\' feature?  EDIT: Whoops
column12: hit the \'Close and Comment\' button when I posted this. >.<"'

column10: b'b\' We have #3980 for facebook
column11: #4156 for twitter and #4331 for tumblr. #4321 introduced wordpress as a supported service and afaik we don\\\'t delete wordpress posts. Is that right? In that case that would be the only service left so I\\\'d change the title to "Delete posts from wordpress when original post has been deleted".\''

column11: so it might take a little while.)"'

column10: b'b" @andrewcsmith Basically
column11: what would need to happen is that you\'d need to make [OmniAuth]url  support connecting to Wordpress. Some work has been done on an [Omniauth Wordpress]url  Gem
column12: but the last commit was from over a year ago
column13: so your mileage may vary in working with it. If you\'re up for the challenge
column14: there\'s [an outdated doc]url  that illustrates the basics of what would need to happen."'

column10: b"b' I was thinking I would begin by using the  [REST API]url  which would take care of a large number of users. Would that be an okay start? (Realizing that the original poster might be talking about )'"
b'b" Wouldn\'t that be a bit limiting? I\'d imagine the majority of all wordpress blogs aren\'t hosted there. Hm
column11: but then it would be impossible to do oAuth anyway."'

column10: b'b" Ideally
column11: it\'d be great if a Wordpress service connector could be used for authenticating with any Wordpress installation. However
column12: there are a few caveats:Wordpress self-hosted setups typically don\'t come with oAuth. This means anyone self-hosting must either find an extension to include such functionality
column13: or they\'d have to leverage the [XML-RPC API]url This also basically means that
column14: unfortunately
column15: setting up the connector for self-hosters would require following a set of steps for getting their proper application keys and secrets entered. While anyone with a little technical know-how can do this
column16: this creates way more steps for the end user. It\'s not as simple as
column17: say
column18: authenticating to Facebook or other centralized social services.As I said before
column19: service connectors are put together with different OmniAuth strategies from inside the Diaspora app. Each strategy corresponds to each service.Finally
column20: you\'d need to make sure the markdown was properly converted upon being sent to a Wordpress blog. so as to remain readable."'

column10: b'b" Right
column11: what about suggesting possible oAuth plugins that could be used? I just came across this one: url  Anyone know how the Wordpress mobile app does it
column12: and if it\'s worth looking into?"'

column11: I guess I was talking about Wordpress the software (.org) though I hadn\'t really considered what the technical side of this might be. On the other hand

column13: url  Cheers!"'

column10: b"b' Post visible for mentioned people Post was NOT shared with them!'"
b"b' We hat a serious bug on Diaspora 0.1.0.0 a user created a post
column11: shared with an aspect that did not contain Person A.Person A was mentioned in the post and hat the post delivered to his stream
column12: despite the post was not shared with him.Person A could not comment or like the post and the single-post-view was not loaded
column13: a white page was shown instead.Person A did receive a mention-notification. Desired Behaviour: The post should not be visible to the mentioned person and the person should not receive a notification unless the person is in the choosen aspect or the post is public.'"

column10: b'b" Weird
column11: we talked about this case yesterday with @MrZYX and he said that the user does not see the post. I\'ll try to reproduce it when I\'ll have time.."'

column10: b'b" I think regardless of whether Person A is in the aspect
column11: if the post mentions Person A
column12: Person A should be notified and the post should be visible to them.  I only say this because
column13: what\'s the point of mentioning Person A in the post if they\'re not going to be notified?"'

column10: b'b\' @Ruxton That would me a violation of what the user thinks he is doing.If a user chooses an aspect for a post
column11: the user wants EXACTLY these people to see the post. If the user mentions somebody
column12: the user maybe wants to talk with the aspect about something and wants to refer to the mentiones user and link to the mentioned users profile. The only thing I could think of would be to show a warning: "You are about to mention someone who won\\\'t be seeing this post
column13: because the user is not in the aspect you are posting to."This way the user remains in control and can decide. But programming this behavious would mean some more checking when the user gets mentioned while writing the post. Also the user who writes the post won\\\'t be able to add the user to the aspect while writing the post (only if the user uses a second browser window and then the containing contacts may be cached by the first window...).Okay
column14: one last idea: You could show the warning and have a checkbox for "add the user to the targer aspect when submitting". Unless you select that checkbox
column15: the post can not be sent while you are mentioning that user. I think the easiest way is just not to mention that person. But the above solution might also be worth thinking about.\''

column10: b"b' Best solution for me.'"
b'b\' Maybe a more reasonable UX workaround would be to somehow limit mentionsbased on what Aspects a post is made in? (That is to say
column11: you can onlymention people in selected Aspects
column12: otherwise their names don\\\'t come up asmentions). For example
column13: you could mention just about anybody in a Publicpost
column14: but if my brother is in "Family" and I try to mention him in a postto "Party Friends" that he\\\'s clearly not a part of
column15: his name just doesn\\\'tcome up there. Just a thought. I don\\\'t really think that explicitly telling the user thattheir contact isn\\\'t going to see a post is exactly going to fix the problem. On Tue
column16: May 21

column13: before writing the post. Hm. @Flaburgan That is additional to the fix I descibed in the first post. You can mention somebody (and get the warning) AND that person won\'t be able to see the post or receive notifications about it."'

column10: b"b' For reference with curl 7.32 Debian enabled the threaded resolver which also solves this problem. It is currently in unstable. For more informations see url  and the following message. A more in depth explanation of the issue can be found here: url '"

b"b' @MrZYX On wheezy I tried curl 7.32 from jessie but without success. Workaround for Debian Wheezy: Install c-ares1. unpack the c-ares archive2. cd c-ares-dir3. ./configure4. make5. make install Remove Debian packages1. apt-get purge curl2. apt-get purge libcurl3 with dependencies Install curl with c-ares1. unpack the curl archive2. cd curl-dir3. ./configure enable-ares=/4. make6. make install Check curl versioncurl versioncurl 7.32.0  c libssh2/1.4.2 '"
b"b' Got hit by this too :P There is also an Ubuntu bug on Launchpad url  hopefully 7.32 will be packaged there too soon to some PPA.'"

column10: b'b" I haven\'t made it all the way through the install (yet)
column11: but if you follow the guide for Debian Wheezy
column12: you should already have a version of libc-ares2 and libc-ares-dev installed? (or you can install them if needed) and just be able to build curl from source against it: Remove Debian packages1. apt-get purge curl2. apt-get purge libcurl3 Install curl with c-ares1. wget url 2. tar zxvf curl-7.33.0 2. cd curl-7.33.03. ./configure enable-ares4. make6. make install7. run ldconfig -v to cache  Check curl versioncurl versioncurl 7.33.0 (x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu)  c libssh2/1.4.2 Protocols: dict file ftp ftps gopher http https imap imaps ldap ldaps pop3 pop3s rtmp rtsp scp sftp smtp smtps telnet tftp Features: AsynchDNS IDN IPv6 Largefile NTLM NTLM_WB SSL libz TLS-SRP ===========UPDATE==========I have it all working now as well and see no issues with sidekiq"'

column11: and explicitly reports the AsynchDNS feature. _worth noting that this took a really long time (over an hour) to build on a newly created dual core 2Ghz Linux container with 2GB RAM._ Proof: Build artifacts directory listing I\'m not sure if I should publish these binaries since they haven\'t been tested. I\'m going to install them on my production pod at url  and cross my fingers. Here\'s the Build-Depends of my control file. This is the only modification I made other than installing the build deps. If you want to build and test this backport yourself
column12: it\'s pretty easy but don\'t do the build on your production server. I suggest creating a VM or Linux Container (Docker is quite useful for something like this). column10: b"b' Email notifications should not include summaries from limited posts'"
b'b\' At present
column11: when someone else comments on a limited post that a user has made or commented on
column12: while their email notifications are switched on
column13: that user will receive an unencrypted email that includes a few sentences from the start of the latest comment
column14: and using the first sentence of the original post in the email\\\'s subject line. This presents a vulnerability to breach of privacy. Some people may still want that summary in their limited notifications
column15: but only after providing D\\\\* with a public key to use so that they can receive it securely. IMO this should be Murphy\\\'s-Law-safe
column16: i.e. "if something can be done wrong
column17: someone will eventually do it wrong"
column18: so ideally there should be no summary or subject for such notifications
column19: merely a note that someone has responded
column20: with a link to the relevant post. Otherwise
column21: those who do need that privacy may be too worried about their contacts\\\' unknown security measures to post some things. There are plenty of examples of social networks and forum software that do not include the content of a private message in email notifications
column22: and such a feature could even save a tiny fraction of server time & bandwidth by not having to fetch and write that data into emails.\''

column10: b'b" I agree that we have a problem here. But what\'s the solution... ? Asking people to generate and upload cryptographic keys is far away of user-friendly..."'
b'b" That\'s _a_ solution
column11: for those who want encrypted verbose notifications
column12: but as I said
column13: a far easier and more reliably secure option is to simply remove that content section of email notifications for limited posts (even simpler would be removing it across the board
column14: including public posts
column15: but that\'s probably going too far)
column16: and give them a generic subject line
column17: possibly mentioning whose activity you\'re being notified of and whether it was on one of your own posts
column18: instead of pasting the OP\'s first line."'

column10: b"b' A short summary of the issues #4342 and #4266: This issue #4266 suggests that the email notifications received from limited posts should not contain any content
column11: only a note that someone has responded (or commented) to the original post while #4342 suggests that the email notifications received from the public posts should provide the full content of the thread in the email itself and the user should be able to answer to the comments via email.  (Please correct me in case I have not perceived the issues properly)'"

column10: b'b" I can\'t speak for #4342
column11: but that sounds about right."'

column10: b"b' We already have a key generated for each user. The ideal situationwould be to allow users to set their e-mail client to receive encryptede-mail. We could then send the total message in every use case.'"
b"b' Is it possible to include a button
column11: clicking on which will automatically generate a private key for a user or will ask a user to generate a private key for themselves?'"

column10: b"b' @sjain1107 the trick here is twofold imo: 1) If d\\\\* generates the keypair
column11: then how does the user know it is not compromised from the start? Does the user trust the d\\\\* pod
column12: and more importantly
column13: should the user ultimately trust the d\\\\* pod?2) If the user generates the keypair
column14: we need a _very_ userfriendly way to upload the public key
column15: or refer to it
column16: since making this unfriendly will make the solution less used'"

column10: b'b" @WebSpider trusting your pod is the key of diaspora*. If you don\'t trust your pod
column11: nothing is secure there. @sjain1107 a user already has a private key. I don\'t know if we can use it with GPG."'

column10: b'b" @WebSpider
column11: For a user to upload a private key
column12: I\'d suggest a field in the Account settings page
column13: \'Upload your private key\'. I\'m not sure that trusting a private key from a pod would lead to any more privacy leak if that pod is \'bad\' than does trusting that same pod with all the information you\'re putting into D\\\\* anyway would it?"'

column10: b"b' I think everything beyond checking the various keyservers for a public key associated with the target mail address is overkill.'"
b"b' What can be the most userfriendly way to  a public key for notification emails?'"
b"b' We need to send encrypted emails only for a public post. The limited posts should not contain any content in the email notification.(encrypted or unencrypted).'"
b'b" Public posts are.... public. No need to encrypted them
column11: everybody can already read them. The encryption is only about private posts. If we decide to remove the content in the email notification for private posts
column12: we don\'t need to encrypted anything."'

column10: b"b' @Flaburgan Well correct. The public post email notifications must be encrypted only in case the user wants to respond to the post activity via email itself. :)'"
b"b' When someone comments on a limited post the subject still includes the beginning of the limited post.'"
b"b' Fixed by #5843.'"

b"b' Two factor authentication'"
b"b' I think there should be two step verification as well.Use open ID can be usefull too.##   The **[$100 bounty]url  on this issue has been claimed at [Bountysource]url  '"
b"b' I have privacy concerns about SSO in the current environment except in the case where the individual is their own authority
column11: which as I understand it is not how the marketing funnel is setup to collect data into third party data stores. Every solution so far that does not keep the decision to provide identity
column12: and the exact extent of information provided
column13: to the network directly and solely at the individuals discretion is wholly unrelated to privacy
column14: regardless of stated policies claiming the opposite.'"

column10: b'b" I saw a bounty was posted on this issue which I guess means we should at least think about how this could be implemented. AFAIK
column11: two-factor identification usually means SMS. I don\'t believe that is a possibility in the decentralized environment where hundreds of podmins would have to start signing up to SMS gateways
column12: which probably are not free to use. Are there any other possibilities outside SMS for two factor authentication which would work in a decentralized environment? If not
column13: I suggest we strongly think about closing this issue from the core so that at least bounties will not be fruitlessly wasted on something that is not possible to implement in a decentralized world in a way that _most_ of the podmins will be able to activate the feature."'

b"b' The issue is that takes the closing as part of the URL url  so we get which 404s and gets the OpenGraph tags of that page. We likely have the same issue with OEmbed url  This can fairly easy be fixed by passing instead of to  . Though in this particular case it would mean that no OpenGraph preview would be generated since we only attempt to fetch it for the first URL. But I consider looking at all URLs in the post as a feature request since it would need some larger restructurings.'"

column10: b'b\' Well it seems I was right after all after a whole discussion of \\\'Yes\\\' and \\\'No\\\' and a shit ton of anger (Sorry still pissed off about it and I won\\\'t call their names right @jaywink ). Also when confronting of a new fact which did not quite taken serious with \\\'corrections\\\' towards me from @jhass  wile it was a literal  from Facebook. At least we got this stuff got out of the way and yet I want to throw in another issue which came on 28th of March. As of March 28 Facebook has rolled out Facebook API V2.3 (Bit earlier but the rules apply from 28th) they have applied several **NEW** rules. There is a **requirement** of having a **JavaScript SDK** which is connected straight to **Facebook** their tracking system. This includes having a **\\\'Signup with Facebook!\\\'** on the landing page and a bonus of privacy stab in the back you have to install **Facebook JavaScript SDK** which has the ability to track the activity on your pod. As a joke on 1st of April of team@ at \\\'post guid\\\' **** came quite close to what the features of the **JavaScript SDK** offers (feel the irony?). **Every thing in a list:**You are required to have a **Sign up with Facebook** button on the landing page
column11: Install **JavaScript SDK** from Facebook
column12: Agree with their "Privacy Policy"
column13: Allow them to track your users and your self on Facebook. This info came from an old friend that continuously makes money with Facebook apps. And he has recently informed a lawyer for an explanation which I got confirmed trough phone. Because of the reason I kind of felt stabbed in the back (last time and I am still feeling it) you have to verify it your own at url  / Well known privacy policy. Or simply use a search engine or ask a common developer from Facebook which is already familiar with this system and policies (what I did).\''

b'b" PostgreSQL database name other than \'postgres\'"'

b'b" It seems that Diaspora only supports the PostgreSQL default database name \'postgres\'. I have a setup where the same database server has multiple different databases. That cannot be easily changed. I would like to deploy Diaspora in a logical database named \'diaspora_db\'
column11: (not \'postgres\'). Could you please make the database name configurable
column12: which is the normal practice with any solution. Or am I missing something?  "'

column10: b"b' The database name is configurable url  How are you setting up diaspora? The normal install guides or some custom packaging?'"
b"b' Also the default database name is diaspora_production not postgres (or diaspora_development for dev env and diaspora_test for test env).'"
b'b" Okay
column11: now I understand the idea of the database configuration file
column12: thanks! @jaywink I\'m using (writing) a fully automated deployment method based on Ansible. Deployment of PostgreSQL databases is a part of the automated process
column13: already written earlier. It would be preferable for my setup to be able to deploy the databases by the usual process and then just give the already existing (new
column14: empty) databases to Diaspora. If I read you guys right
column15: I could deploy databases with those names using my existing automation and then deploy Diaspora on top of that? I have based the deployment automation on the Diaspora standard production deployment on CentOS 7."'

column10: b"b' All diaspora wants in production in the default configuration is a database with the name diaspora_production and rights to create tables
column11: indices and foreign key constraints. And again
column12: the database name is configurable
column13: you can essentially pick whatever you want.'"

column10: b'b" It was most likely some bug with the Ansible script. (Un)fortunately I can no longer reproduce this problem
column11: so I\'m not sure what eventually fixed it. Nevertheless the problem is solved. I created the diaspora_production database first with a separate script
column12: granted Diaspora all the necessary permissions
column13: and then installed Diaspora. The database I created does not have a locale set (LC_ALL=C) and has Unicode encoding. I did get the following warning
column14: but I\'m assuming it\'s not an issue(?):  Please let me know
column15: if I should use a more specific locale. I\'m happy to update the relevant wiki pages
column16: if there\'s some valuable info."'

column10: b'b" You can take out the db:create to skip the first warning and ignore the other two. creates databases with a default encoding of utf8 and I would recommend you to follow that when creating the database via other means. It also should try to escalate privileges when the specified user is not allowed to create database
column11: which is why it\'s fine for manual installation. Actually it only seems to do that for MySQL
column12: but I expect most PostgreSQL users to be able to handle that. I still see no bug in diaspora or the instructions here
column13: so closing."'

b'b" Liking a post shouldn\'t subscribe to it"'

b'b\' When testing the RC 0.5.0.0 several people noticed: You subscribe to the post when you like the post.This is different then before previous to RC 0.5.0.0 you would only subscripte to a post when you comment on the post. I don\\\'t know if this is intentional
column11: but it is an important change in user interaction design and if intentional it should be discussed (maybe it has been
column12: then sorry for not noticing).I often "like" posts just flying by and don\\\'t want to have my notifications spammed by default. I also often think quite a lot before commenting: "Do I want to add my 2 cents and risk to get the whole load of notifications about comments which are uninteresting because I had that discussion several times... or do I just like it and be done with it." So if this is intentional
column13: the default should be configurable or it should be changed to "do not subscribe on like" like it was in previous versions.##   Want to back this issue? **[Post a bounty on it!]url  We accept bounties via [Bountysource]url  \''

column10: b'b\' A bit background: The subscription is based on what we call participations. A like always created a participation
column11: so did a comment or a reshare. The new "subscribe to post" feature works by creating a participation but no other interaction with the post. The list of people to notify is determined by who has a participation for that post
column12: previously we checked whether a comment by the recipient existed before creating the notification
column13: but that wouldn\\\'t work for the "subscribe to post" feature. So it could be said the new behavior is a compromise to be able to implement the "subscribe to post" feature without a large redesign of the codebase or adding a second huge table to manage them explicitly. This was changed in #5511\''

column10: b'b\' Thanks a lot for the explaination!Maybe it will turn out a good feature to have yourself notified about comments on post you did only "like". Maybe not... at least the behaviour is more consistent now from a programmers point of view. As diaspora is a changing community-project
column11: we might try this and make adjustments later... sorry for the "boa
column12: things changed
column13: I have to make a big deal of it" issue but it shows how we need to have a good "user transition guide" or something to show people what changed in the new release
column14: so they are not as surprised and will not start thinking of these things as bugs. :)\''

column10: b'b" Well
column11: thinking about it
column12: we could easily add a flag in the participations table whether notifications for it should be generated or not
column13: it\'s just our biggest table
column14: so even that bit for the flag will likely blow it up quite a bit further."'

column10: b'b\' Hm... I think "make good defaults and not so many settings" may have been one of the design principles we tend to use... otherwise I would say it could be simple to just generate a participation when clicking "like" and having a "follow on like" option (per user) enabled in the settings. That would not have something to do with the participations table but more with the user table which has a lot less rows.\''
b"b' No
column11: the main purpose of the participations table is to track which users (and thus pods) should receive interactions with a post
column12: the notifications are only the second step after that.'"

column10: b"b' I understand that. If a user is not added to the participations table (for that post) the user will not receive interactions. If I like a post but will not be added to the table
column11: the behaviour will be as it was in the old version. Whether someone is added to the table or not could be controlled by a user-specific setting that is evaluated when the user clicks the like-button.'"

column10: b'b\' Note that now you can also unsubscribe to notification
column11: so no need to think a lot about "do I have to comment and be spammed"
column12: you can comment / like and immediately stop receiving notification for the post ;)\''

column10: b'b\' @Flaburgan I know that. I just don\\\'t want to hit "unsubscribe" 100x when I like 100 posts where I don\\\'t want any notifications and "just" liked them.\''
b'b\' @Flaburgan Yes
column11: that\\\'s really a good feature
column12: absolutely agree. I also see now a bit the background of the table and coding "problems".But from in practical view on "the other side" it\\\'s not done with disabling the notifications that\\\'s also only the second step. If I like a post by clicking
column13: then in background the subscription already happens
column14: but the button appears as disabled. So we have to refresh the page and scroll back
column15: or to open the post itself
column16: to make the notifications-button usable to disable them.\''

column11: We have a few users who can\'t see \'all\' notifications because they get an error 500. This is because of some checks that are lacking in the NotificationController. As you can see. Some notifications are rendered but then an error 500 is generated. ##   Want to back this issue? **[Post a bounty on it!]url  We accept bounties via [Bountysource]url  "'

column11: the users with a notification from that account got a 500.'"

column10: b"b' Yes that is what I personally think that is the problem. But now I need a solution :) I deleted some spam accounts back when we started.'"

b"b' Well the solution would have been to use the admin panel to delete the account instead of do a directly in the database. Now you have to search in your DB which participations are orphan and edit them. '"

b'b" True that should have been the way but shouldn\'t there be a check in the controller to prevent 500? Because we also had accounts that had error 500 because somebody changed his profile image. Simple basic change but caused an error 500. Personally I think better checking is also part of the solution."'
b'b\' "Error 500" is not a specific error
column11: it\\\'s the symptom of any _unexpected_ error. There\\\'s no general way to "just prevent" it.\''

column10: b'b" I understand that there is no \'general way\'
column11: but these 2 issues could been prevented by simple checks."'

column10: b"b' Looking forward to your pull requests adding all these obvious simple checks we miss then!'"

b'b" I understand feedback can be hard to handle on a personal level. That\'s why you should keep it on the professional level. I love to be part of the D\\\\* idea and I might idd add these checks."'
b"b' Sure

column10: b'b" Neither am I; but nor am I keen on sending a message in English or the podmin\'s language regardless of what language(s) the user speaks. In some cases this will be fine
column11: for instance where a pod is being run for a particular locality
column12: such as diaspora-fr or
column13: but in general I don\'t see sending (potentially) mixed-language messages as worse than always sending a message in one language. I don\'t really see an ideal option here
column14: and I don\'t feel strongly one way or the other. Both approaches have drawbacks. How about this: keep all the default text in one field in . The message sender code could (I hope) check this field against  and
column15: if the two are identical
column16: use the i18n text (which would be identical in the  locale). If
column17: on the other hand
column18: the podmin has made any changes to this field in
column19: this customised text in  will be used rather than any i18n locales. That way messages could be sent in users\' preferred languages _if_ the default text has remained unchanged
column20: but if the podmin has customised the text
column21: it will be sent to each user in the language set by the podmin. A note that the welcome message will not be localised if the podmin changes the text could be added to the explanation of this feature in ."'

column10: b'b" If there is any text I can add to the default to make it less likely for a podmin to feel they need to customise the text (i.e. information that would be useful to users of any pod)
column11: let me know and I\'ll add it. If we decide to stick with the fixed-language message for now
column12: I can make a PR with that text once everyone\'s happy with the default text unless either @TwizzyDizzy or @fapwants to do it and localisation can be a later refinement
column13: if we can find an elegant solution."'

column10: b'b" Yeah
column11: I guess having the default localized and have the config option override the localized version is the best compromise. Though I think I actually wouldn\'t even mind to not make it configurable at all."'

column11: there really should be a spec to follow for contributors because HTML and CSS are a mess. Something like a good practice guide. I have a idea or to
column12: just throwing here for now. E.g : every CSS classe should use dash
column13: not camel or snake case. And we definitely should seperate classes used for selecting in JS from these used for CSS. An idea should be that no HTML class used to select in JS should have any CSS rule and should be clearly distinct from CSS customization class by a prefix for instance. Any class starting with for instance should be only used for JS operations while anything else should be used for CSS rules. It would easy the the refactor preccess by preventing to remove break JS logic whil removing useless or deprecated class. Just saying.'"

column10: b'b\' Thank you very much for insulting us. I guess you are aware we had this discussion before
column11: but I will explain it to you once again so you have another chance to understand it. First of all
column12: nobody is forcing you to contribute to this open source project. You do this on your own will and I appreciate the amount of time you put into collaborating. However

column15: @jhass and myself got added by the core team because they valued our contributions. So at any given point
column16: you have to understand that
column17: in doubt
column18: we are the ones doing decisions. This has nothing to do with dictatorship
column19: but with plain project management. And you do have to deal with our feedback if you want to get your work merged into the projects core. You submitted a pull request here. If someone opens a pull request in this project
column20: I get both an email and a desktop notification that somebody wants their code merged or is looking for feedback. Usually
column21: one of the project members will have a look at it within hours. I got your pull request and immediately realized that this is neither a working contribution nor code you have written yourself. While the first one is okay since this PR is clearly marked as a work in progress
column22: the second issue is something I simply can not and will not accept. Given the fact I occasionally do get paid for open source work and I am in fact one of the elected owners of the diaspora projects
column23: I assume I do know the open source world quite a bit. You pulled sources made by other people without giving them any credit. That is unacceptable for multiple reasons: First
column24: you do in fact violate copyright law here. If GitHub gets a complaint
column25: they will check the issue and either delete your repository or even your account. As a project with over 10.000 stars
column26: we have to make sure we do not run into any troubles. Secondly
column27: the person writing this code also spent a lot of time in writing it and I can safely assume the codes authors put more time into it than you did with pulling it. What you did is ethically wrong and I do not care if this is a work in progress or not. Last but not least

column10: b'b\' OAuth2 and OIDC are basically the same. OIDC is just a particular application of OAuth2. So
column11: if an implmentation of OIDC is made
column12: an implementation of OAuth2 is also made. The two relies on the same concepts: an application gets token and uses them to consume resources. In the case of OAuth2
column13: these resources are undefined. In the case of OIDC
column14: the resource is an identity. Basically
column15: the same flows can be used for both. I\\\'ve only implemented the user credential flow to provide tokens but the goal is to provide the 4 different flows. Then
column16: the tokens can be used to do anything the API let the application do. In a short term
column17: let\\\'s stick with OIDC and say the API is limited to provide identity informations (the famous "connect with " on the websites). But in a middle term
column18: this can be extended to provide means to post
column19: get streams
column20: add and query contacts
column21: etc... I initially started to implement the password flow first because it was the easiest to manage for me. It\\\'s that simple ;)\''

column10: b'b\' @AugierLe42e "OAuth2 and OIDC are basically the same. OIDC is just a particular application of OAuth2. So
column11: if an implmentation of OIDC is made
column12: an implementation of OAuth2 is also made. The two relies on the same concepts: an application gets token and uses them to consume resources. In the case of OAuth2
column13: these resources are undefined. In the case of OIDC
column14: the resource is an identity." Yeah I\\\'m with you until here.  "Basically
column15: the same flows can be used for both. I\\\'ve only implemented the user credential flow to provide tokens but the goal is to provide the 4 different flows." From what I read
column16: there is no password flow in OIDC
column17: that is an OAuth2 only concept. I assume this is because it defeats the purpose of OIDC to provide the client application (RP) with your password. All three of the OIDC flows (auth code
column18: implicit
column19: hybrid) rely on having the user authenticate with the OP (e.g.
column20: Diaspora pod) and then the OP passes the access tokens to the RP (e.g.
column21: a native mobile application). "Then
column22: the tokens can be used to do anything the API let the application do. In a short term
column23: let\\\'s stick with OIDC and say the API is limited to provide identity informations (the famous "connect with " on the websites)." Yeah this sounds like a good plan. Basically the only point I want to make is that I would like to add a redirect to our initial plans.1. Client should click the "Connect with Diaspora" button on the native app2. Client is redirected to a Diaspora pod3. Client logins to a Diaspora pod and authorizes the native app (note how the native app will never get the user\\\'s Diaspora pod password)4. Client is redirected back to the native app with the access token (we can skip the ID token for now)5. Client should be able to get identity information from the user-info endpoint using the access token Edit: Ok after going through Nov\\\'s application again
column24: I realized that the password flow is a convinient way to test that the user-info endpoint works (aka the part where we use the access token to obtain the user\\\'s identity). I just want to make sure we are on the same page in that we will be using the password flow just to test our user-info endpoint and our goal isn\\\'t to provide 4 different flows defined by the OAuth2 RFC 6749 specification but instead to provide the 3 different flows defined by OIDC. The auth code and the implicit flows that are defined by both OAuth2 and OIDC are similar but OAuth2 is a bit more vague. OAuth2 RFC 6749
column25: 1.2. Protocol Flow
column26: states that in the first step  "The client requests authorization from the resource owner. The authorization request can be made directly to the resource owner (as shown)
column27: or preferably indirectly via the authorization server as an intermediary." Instead of "preferably indirectly via the authorization server as an intermediary
column28:
I want to make sure that we are planning to definitely authorize via the authorization server as specified by the OIDC spec. So in terms of where we are headed next, I suggest we implement Nov\\\'s UserInfoController equivalent, especially the part. Once we can successfully obtain the user\\\'s identity through cUrl, we should move on to implement OIDC\\\'s implicit flow as I outlined before this edit. For this we will need an actual client app just like Nov\\\'s RP sample unless we can somehow handle redirects with cUrl. Once we finish OIDC\\\'s implicit flow, we should then drop support for the password flow as we no longer need it. Either way, we should then move on to implement the other 2 OIDC flows. What do you say?\''

diaspora	6095	closed	27	AugierLe42e	2015-06-12 21:29:08	49.18		+1		b'b\' No, it\\\'s not about this. In the case of the "Connect with..." button, the redirection address has to be previously known in an OIDC flow. But, in the case of a distributed network like diaspora*, this address isn\\\'t well known until the user indicates a pod, which adds a step and a certain level of complexity client side. So, this part of the flow when the user gives his pod is not a part of an OIDC flow, but is still a prerequisite, client side, to start an OIDC flow. (Not sure I\\\'m being clear, right now)\''

For cases where the RP can\'t or shouldn\'t be informed, we should display a nice error page.A link to the spec that states it as optional would be very reassuring ;)I would expect so, just registers a method to be called, it does not invoke things in a special callback registry. column10: b'b" [Getting Started] The aspect combobox doesn\'t reload when creating a new aspect"'
b'b" On the getting started page
column11: when you have been invited by someone
column12: there is an aspect selection dropdown to put the person in an aspect. This dropdown allows you to create a new aspect. Once you submitted the modal
column13: the aspect dropdown doesn\'t contain the new created aspect
column14: so you can\'t select it.##   The **[$15 bounty]url  on this issue has been claimed at [Bountysource]url  "'

column10: b'b" By comparing it to the profile page\'s aspect combobox\'s contact backbone view ()
column11: the getting started page\'s aspect membership backbone view (aspect_membership_) is missing a handler. Throwing the line in line 25 of aspect_membership_ fixes the problem but I\'m not sure if this is good practice."'

column10: b'b" This quick hack would cause reloading of the whole page... that\'s not convenient. I will refactor the aspect-dropdown to a true backbone-component (currently the HTML is generated via ruby and updated via ajax when you populare a hovercard...). When this is a backbone-component
column11: the client can manipulate the aspect-dropdown in any possible way
column12: so adding a newly created aspect to the already shown list should be straight forward instead of consist of a series of hacks. :)"'

column10: b"b' Once you ported the aspect dropdown to a backbone template you can just rerender it on change.'"
b'b" That\'s my plan. :)"'
b"b' @Faldrian this issue is currently a blocker for the 0.6 release. Do you plan to work on it in the coming weeks?'"
b"b' No
column11: sorry. I stopped working on this issue some time ago
column12: sorry for the missing status update. As far as I can see I will not continue working on this.'"

column11: so adding xmpp as a protocol would be wrong. In url  was decided to use xmpp in for systems federating over xmpp like movim. For chat diaspora added in c928d6c."'

While the website UI is broken (for all intents and purposes anyway) I started using Pidgen to log into my pod\'s XMPP server.  I\'m regularly chatting with people on Pluspora and elsewhere not just my pod.  "'
b"b'  Could it be added instead to the services array alongside Twitter
column11: Tumblr and WordPress?'"

column10: b'b"  You can talk to every other XMPP user
column11: not only diaspora pods
column12: it\'s a normal XMPP account.  But as said
column13: diaspora doesn\'t federate messages through XMPP. That was discussed too url  but services are for things where you can forward posts to
column14: and diaspora doesn\'t support that either."'

column10: b'b"  Only as outbound
column11: since NodeInfo forbids inbound XMPP.. \\xf0\\x9f\\xa5\\x87 \\xf0\\x9f\\x8e\\x96 \\xf0\\x9f\\x8f\\x85 \\xf0\\x9f\\x8f\\x86 Anyway
column12: if the Diaspora project doesn\'t want it to show in the protocols then it is their decision. I would argue the Diaspora server does have federating XMPP if the server maintainer installs an XMPP server and integrates it to Diaspora. Unrelated
column13: but the reason I came to comment here. We can solve this on the-federation info side as it is anyway necessary to allow multiple platforms running on the same domain name. In this case XMPP server maintainers can expose for example NodeInfo2 for the XMPP server
column14: thus getting both listed thought as separate instances."'

column10: b'b" Don\'t retry dead pods indefinately"'
b'b\' Currently we seem to retry dead pods if not forever
column11: then for a long time at least. Currently
column12: for a recent post I made
column13: I had **89 failures** for outgoing sidekiq jobs. I can only imagine how much extra weight this is putting on large long running pods. So what I would propose is to either;Add a "retry_next" timestamp which would be set on a failure. It would start as "1s" and increase exponentally each time a failure occurs. When a job needs to be done
column14: the pod first checks whether this pod should be retried or not
column15: if timestamp exists
column16: and if not
column17: it would just brutally skip the job.After say "local users*1000" failures or something that somehow takes into account pod size
column18: queue deletion of pod entry and all local content from that pod. Brutal but would clean up for real users. Here is the list as a fyi
column19: from the post on my pod. A few I know might not be permanently down
column20: but most are and many of these names have gone years ago.  ##  Want to back this issue? **[Post a bounty on it!]url  We accept bounties via [Bountysource]url  \''

column10: b"b' Related but not similar. 4183 talks about manual cleanup actions. This talks about tuning the federation layer so it would more intelligently just not bang its head against a brick wall indefinitely.'"

column11: connection
column12: HTTP) some time ago. ([Here is a Gist]url My idea back then was to add a list of pods to the admin section and list them as  and state the reason in case it\'s not responding and for how long that has been the case. column16: @SuperTux88?'"

column10: b'b" I\'m kinda finished
column11: it\'s left to make a release of the diaspora_federation. It covers only a few cases of federation receive
column12: but I think it\'s better to merge it and then add more tests in further commits
column13: so we don\'t stay with the opened vulnerability."'

column10: b'b" I realized that some of situations tested here are artificial (e.g. [here]url  In real life
column11: it\'s not possible
column12: or just doesn\'t make sense
column13: that sender makes right signature for Salmon and then fails to make a signature for the payload using the same key. Thus
column14: I\'ll rewrite tests in consideration that we only test situations where the both signatures (Salmon and in-payload
column15: like in relayables) are correct or both signatures are wrong."'

column10: b"b' Also consider the situation of a malicious user and pod owner ;)'"
b'b" Sure
column11: it is considered
column12: it is the only reason why we need signatures atall :) ATM we have a situation where entity in payload
column13: for example commentgets signed by the key of a user
column14: and then packed in Salmon
column15: and Salmongets signed with the same key again. There isn\'t much sense to checkcases
column16: when one signature is ok and the other is broken (moreover
column17: weprobably just don\'t need these duplicating signatures at all
column18: see #6566). The fun is that the only case when a signature in the entity is in factuseful([this]url is the one where we don\'t check it now :) I guess that there maybe was some idea behind it
column19: like they wanted
column20: forexample
column21: to make pods exchange messages in P2P style
column22: like pod A posteda status
column23: pod B fetched the status and resent it to pod C
column24: which resentit to pod D. That would explain why they duplicated signatures in thepayloads but not only in signed envelopes
column25: and that would explain whythey wanted to keep signatures in the database. But we don\'t do that
column26: somost of this signatures code is redundant for us."'

column11: this information is useless. "This is Markdown" is better to this regards.Another option is to put a link "Help on Markdown formatting" or "Markdown formatting tips": this way we keep it short and we materialize the relation between the current formatting and the "Markdown" word.\''

column14: **everything** is markdown na? So when we say

column10: b'b\' I disagree. When you know this is related to formatting
column11: you understand. But if it is the first time you read it
column12: Markdown supported" is not very clear. Is it another social network? a device? a language? We could have written "Twitter supported
column13: as it is possible to post to this platform... I may be wrong
column14: but as I understand it
column15: when you write some feature is supported
column16: you generally inform the user who knows the feature and may be looking for it he can find it here. This is not a good formulation to introduce a new concept.\''

column10: b"b' Unlike seems to fail if the Post-owner is on the same pod. How is connected defined? '"
b'b" @abimelex thanks for the clarification. By [connected] I meant that the post\'s owner is in your contacts. Now
column11: I can confirm that the bug occurs when you unlike a post owned by a user who is not in your contacts. I\'ll try to send a fix for this issue as soon as possible.  Thanks
column12: Sayed"'

column10: b'b" @abimelex
column11: It turns out that deleting a comment on a public post fails too if the post\'s owner isn\'t in the commenter contacts or the commenter isn\'t in the post\'s owner contacts. So Here the steps to reproduce both bugs: Given two not-connected users A and B:1As User A publish a public post.2As User B like the post and comment on it.3As long as User B isn\'t in user A contacts or User A isn\'t in user B contacts
column12: User  B wont be able to unlike the post or delete his own comment. The expected behaviour:Given that the post is public then User B should be able to unlike the post and delete his comment without having to add User A to his contacts. Thanks
column13: Sayed"'

column10: b'b" @abimelex
column11: @jhass  In diaspora both like and comment are Relayable objects and the actions of unliking a public post or deleting a comment are delegated to the  instance method. While the  method is in charge
column12: it does the following:Builds RelayableRetraction object.Builds Postzord::Dispatcher object
column13: that returns an instance of Postzord::Dispatcher::Private then send the [post] message to this instance.The post method of Postzord::Dispatcher::Private executes post_to_subscribers on self which in turns executes deliver_to_local on self deliver_to_local starts a sidekiq worker then Workers:: is invoked The perform method of  Workers::Receive instance invokes suppress_annoying_errors (which is inherited from Workers::Base to catch raised exception) with a block that instantiate an instance of Postzord::Receiver::Private then invokes parse_and_receive method on this instanceFinally the parse_and_receive methods invokes validate_object method on self which raises Diaspora::ContactRequiredUnlessRequest exception and prevent the retraction of the RelayableRetraction object. In our example of unliking a public post or deleting a comment on it
column14: the method contact_required_unless_request in Postzord::Receiver::Private class ensures that the post\'s owner has the author in his contact otherwise Diaspora::ContactRequiredUnlessRequest is rasied. The current implementation of this method: A possible fix is to check if the RelayableRetraction object\'s parent is public and if it is return false from contact_required_unless_request which means that contact is not required
column15: a suggested implementation look like this: Thanks
column16: Sayed"'

b'b\' Let me summarize what I wrote on 27th of March and in some more recent comments:Stop posting memory usage numbers unless you are explicitly asked to do so. @Flaburgan \\\'s numbers per queue for example were requested and very useful
column11: they actually led me toward a solution for parts of a problem we had. Pasting  /  outputs is only creating noise. Without detailed information about the memory contents and the full environment
column12: these numbers are totally useless and make this issue look like everyone is whining.No
column13: there is no **leak**. A memory leak is indicated by a constantly growing memory usage without any limit. We\\\'ve had one in the past by reusing cURL sockets (technically that was not even a leak either since it eventually could have reached its limit
column14: but the numbers are way to high on this)
column15: which got fixed. Even for @jaywink
column16: memory consumption seems to be stable now. Nobody in the active development team was able to find an leak
column17: so unless you can prove that there are leaks
column18: there are none.Yes
column19: Sidekiq eats quite a lot of memory. However
column20: compared to
column21: for example GitLab
column22: our memory consumption is quote low if you match up the concurrency settings.If you want to reduce your memory footprint
column23: reduce Sidekiqs concurrency and reduce the size of the database connection pool. If you actually want to contribute to this issue in any way:Figure out if we even need more than
column24: let\\\'s say
column25: 2 sidekiq threads. Our new federation tasks are really fast compared to the old ones and we might not even run into queuing problems with smaller numbers. 5/25 were picked ages ago
column26: with basically everything inside diaspora* looking different. One could
column28: draw charts with average job wait times. If workers are idle most of the time
column29: we could try decreasing the concurrency to increase the worker worktime while keeping the peak job time below 5 minutes
column31: see url  from July. There\\\'s an explicit warning and _"But if enough people experiment with this
column32: we eventually we might gather enough experience in the community to be able to recommend settings for small
column34: which is still true.Understand how the GC in Ruby really works. Maybe
column35: we\\\'re doing something incredibly stupid and the fix is very simple.Understand how memory profiling in Ruby cleanly works and dig further into the memory traces. We know that a lot of memory is allocated inside ActiveRecord bindings
column36: but this information is totally worthless without knowing what\\\'s inside those bindings. Also
column37: figure out on how we can make this more efficient. Don\\\'t ask here
column38: we don\\\'t have an idea. However
column39: please write a blog post or something about this since I would be really interested in learning that. If you feel like everything sucks
column40: feel free to:Submit Pull Requests to Sidekiq to help them improve their memory footprint.Investigate alternative Queuing solutions. Compare and benchmark them. Port diaspora*.Rewrite our workers using
column43: figure out how to build and deploy them for all podmins without having them setting up an entire Go build stack.Build our very own and tailored solution for background processing
column44: with performance and a low footprint in mind. Also
column45: figure out how to build and deploy them for all podmins without having them setting up an entire  build stack. In any case
column46: **stop using this issue for "I am having memory bloat as well" posts**. I will delete all of them that ever appear below this comment. Our GitHub issue tracker is not a support platform
column47: and I don\\\'t want to discuss configuration issues here at all. If we figure out our default settings are bad (which very well may be)
column48: we should change them. If we figure out we can give podmins a better idea of what they should set their concurrency to
column49: we should add that stuff to the wiki. The only things that belong into this issue
column51: are discussions regarding memory improvements we could perform on our side.\''

column10: b"b' Search bar triggeres a a request to load all contacts'"
b"b' Regression of #6293. Due to [:26]url  a request to is made every time the search view gets initialized. Since this json contains literally all the users contacts
column11: users with a large contact base can cause quite a huge amount of traffic and database load... @svbergerem why is the prefetching needed here?##   Did you help close this issue? Go claim the **[$15 bounty]url  on [Bountysource]url  '"

column10: b"b' I guess the request is made to fix #4789
column11: but uh... This is really a bummer. :/'"

column10: b"b' @denschub I guess as for url  we should first get only the user id
column11: name and handle to be able to make the search
column12: and then get all the info we need for the few contacts displayed.'"

column10: b"b' AFAIR we already fetched this before for mentions in the publisher and now we definitely fetch it for both mentions and the search bar. We could create a server side contacts search and use that for mentions. For the search bar we could improve the current search by also searching for contacts. Then we would also get rid of  there and we would really fix #4789. I already tried to implement the second fix but found out that one would need some experience with our database to fix that.'"
b'b" As discussed on IRC
column11: I don\'t think #6951 is a nice fix to this. Triggering a new query to the server each time the user wants to mention someone has at least two flaws:1. the mentionning system is going to get much slower than before #6951 and probably _really_ slow on pods with high traffics (JD
column12: d-fr or Framasphere)
column13: 2. the mentionning system will fail if the server or client temporarily goes offline while the user is typing a message. Allowing the mentionning system to fail even if the page is fully loaded is a bad UX
column14: IMHO
column15: and I really don\'t think the gain is worth it. The search bar and the mentionning dropdown should
column16: at the very least
column17: be fed with the contacts the user is sharing with (the mentionning dropdown actually doesn\'t need more). Gon could be used to feed Bloodhound with the these contacts once and for all when the page is loaded. On the other hand
column18: the mobile view fetching all the contacts that are sharing with the user or the user is sharing with using [this method]url  and the converstion page on mobile view is not slow."'

column10: b'b" I\'m not sure about the perf here. I know my use case is not everybody\'s one
column11: but I have thousands of contacts and each call to  take 6 seconds before the server\'s answer. So if we want to do the search client side
column12: we need to keep the contact list in a cache
column13: but we cannot continue to make a that intensive call to the server each time we refresh the page."'

column10: b'b" I\'m reopening this so we have something open as a reminder to think about this."'
b"b' We need to figure out why this is not problem on mobile view. I think we can reduce the amount of transmitted data. Bloodhound and Typeahead need 4 informations do display a contact: handle
column11: pseudo
column12: guid and avatar url and profile page url. Now profile page url can be deduced from guid so that reduces to 3 fields.Could we consider something like persisting the contacts list in a cookie?'"

column10: b'b" No need to put it in a cookie
column11: we can activate the cache on  . We would then answer with a 304 and the browser will use the cached version. If a modification to the contacts is done by the user we then invalid the cache.I\'m fine with keeping this issue open but the 0.6 milestone can be removed: I don\'t have calls to  anymore when I load /stream."'

column10: b"b' @AugierLe42e have you tested it already? On my dev-pod it works really fast
column11: so I have no idea why you think its slow? Also
column12: on already slow pods
column13: it is better to only be slower when you try to mention someone
column14: instead of being slow every time you load /stream... I think we should close the issue again
column15: because this is fixed. And we can open a new one
column16: if we see that the new search request is slow or has other issues.'"

column10: b'b" Nope. But no need to test to know that triggering an HTTP request is slower than searching locally ;)It\'s not only a question of speed:"'
b'b\' slower yes
column11: but you sounded like "OMG
column12: it is unusable slow now!" ... before this
column13: the whole stream was "unusable" slow for people with many contacts
column14: so it is definitively a improvement compared to before. Maybe it can be improved more
column15: but for now I see this issue done. And if it really is too slow
column16: we should create a new issue for this.the load of the stream will also fail
column17: if the pod is offline
column18: and sending the post will also fail
column19: if the pod is offline ... many things fail if the pod is offline
column20: so what is the advantage of mentioning a user if everything else breaks? And how often do you have the case
column21: that the pod (or you) are only offline for 10 seconds exactly while you press
column22: and everything is online before and after this (to load the page and send the post)?\''

column10: b'b" The user can continue to write posts if the pod is offline. That should be the expected behaviour. That the user cannot interact with the pod when he goes offline is an expected behaviour. The he can\'t even properly write a post is not.It\'s not only the pod. The user himself can also go offline. Actually
column11: it happens to me regularly. And I don\'t expect the mentionning system to fail when my computer temporarily goes offline. If I don\'t
column12: I suppose that lots of user less aware of how diaspora works won\'t expect either."'

b'b\' That\\\'s what volumes are for: you can mount a volume in your container that points to a host directory. I work on the code of diaspora in the host directly and changes are reflected immediately in the container.In the Dockerfile I create the [/diaspora]url  directory and set it to mount my [current directory]url  (where is the diaspora code) when starting the "web" container.url \''
b'b" Docker-compose makes all easier
column11: as it lets you specify how your containers running the required services need to interact together and which image to use (for instance there are official images for redis or postgresql). Nothing else to do : it pulls the specified images
column12: expose the ports you tell it to
column13: run a default command to start whatever service after the containers boot and there
column14: your env is ready. For instance if I\'m tempted to check the chat features (I haven\'t yet) I think I could just add prosody to the mix without it being too painful
column15: and without messing up my system."'
