b'b" I started reviewing your code and got stuck in  . You add in front of handles because otherwise when the user removes a contact from the recipients list you won\'t be able to find out which contact has been removed. This is because [bootstrap-tags]url  only accepts strings as tags. I\'m none too happy about adding hacks to support external libraries
column11: especially if the last release was in 2014 and the only change afterwards was a README update. A feature request that could fix this for us [has been around for more than 2 years]url  I looked around for other libs that are actively maintained and would support adding ids to tags but I wasn\'t able to find any. Your current code looks like we are only using bootstrap-tags to render the tags and call a function when the user removes a tag and do everything else on our own. This is something we could do with a simple backbone view that renders a handlebars template. In this case we would be able to get the diaspora handle and the contact id from the backbone model for the view. We would even be able to add avatars to the list of recipients. (Like url  Before doing any further changes it would be great if you could open a new PR with the backbone port of the conversations view. (your first commit and some parts of the second commit) This makes it easier for me to review the code and we can concentrate later on the changes that might need some further discussion without delaying the backbone port."'

b'b" Just noticed that the themes don\'t follow Diaspora\'s capitalisation guideline. Now fixed. Please note: Homebrew is currently kaput on my machine (going to try to fix this tomorrow) so I can\'t test this PR. As it\'s only changing capitalisation of strings
column11: I hope it won\'t break anything but I\'d be grateful if you\'d confirm this before merging. ps: shouldn\'t these theme names be localised?"'

column10: b'b" I\'m on the fence
column11: I think we can argue for them to be proper nouns. Which then would also mean their current capitalization is correct. Not sure yet what I think about it
column12: have to sleep over it."'

column10: b'b" Don\'t try to sleep on the fence
column11: that\'ll be very uncomfortable! I consider them headings on a par with \'My aspects\'
column12: My activity
column13: #Followed tags\'
column14: and so on; all of which were changed to have only the first letter capitalised. I think they could only be consider proper nouns (in English
column15: at least; and editing English text is where I do have some expertise) if they were recognised colour names
column16: e.g. \'Cerulean Blue\' (although I wouldn\'t capitalise \'blue\' in that in any case). \'Egyptian Blue\' _might_ fall into this category
column17: but not \'dark green\' and certainly not \'original white background\' (which is a description rather than a name
column18: and should probably have a colon after \'Original\'
column19: as should \'Original: dark\'). Anyway
column20: I won\'t argue about it if the team decision is otherwise
column21: but at the moment these strings are inconsistent with the rest of the UI (in English
column22: at least) and I think they would sit more happily in the UI if they were capitalised like the rest. Sleep well!"'

column11: and I agree about _"ps: shouldn\\\'t these theme names be localised?"_ they probably should.\''

b"b' #7013 removed the notifications and conversations icons from the header bar and replaced them with items in the drawer menu. The drawer is now cut off at the bottom
column11: with a scroll bar. I tested this on two browsers: on Firefox 47.0.1
column12: the scroll bar appears only when the user menu has also been opened; on Opera 36.0
column13: the scroll bar appears whether the user menu is closed or open. ![header-mobile-open2]url  One for @svbergerem perhaps?'"

column10: b'b" I tried it with Firefox 45.3 and I only see the scrollbar when the dropdown is higher than 480px (which is exactly what I expected from the code) but that doesn\'t happen on my pod because I didn\'t add the \\xe2\\x80\\x9cMy aspects\\xe2\\x80\\x9d link like @Flaburgan did on diaspora-fr. @AugierLe42e changed the max-height in #6325 from 340px to 480px so now you\'ll need at least 50px (for the header) + 480px (for the dropdown) = 530px height on your device to display the dropdown without any problems. If the  device is not that high the rest of the header will be cut off which is basically something Bootstrap does. Will this be a problem for some devices? Should we go back to 340px? @AugierLe42e what was the reason here to increase the height?"'
b'b" AFAIR
column11: it was to let the menu be entirely displayed so that there\'s no need to scroll to reach the last items."'

column10: b'b" This was viewed on my laptop with a narrow browser window
column11: so testing the responsive \'desktop\' version rather than the discrete \'mobile\' version. The window is higher than 530px 668px in this screenshot (I cropped out the bottom bit before as I had taken the screenshot to use to illustrate the drawer in the tutorials). ![drawer_open]url  I\'m not sure what the best solution is set on the drawer a bit higher
column12: or give a podmin setting in  to add _n_ number of extra items to the drawer which will add an appropriate amount to the max-height if podmin adds extra items?"'

column10: b'b" The risk is to permanently make some menu items unavailable on small devices. If the menu\'s height is higher than the device\'s screen
column11: the user won\'t be able to scroll down to the last items."'

column10: b'b" You will see a scroll bar depending on the max-height. The dropdown won\'t be higher than the max-height and if it needs more space then you\'ll see the scrollbar. Increasing the max-height would mean that parts of the dropdown won\'t be visible on smaller screens at all. Let\'s say your window has a height of 500px. The header has a height of 50px and we currently allow the dropdown to have a height of 480px. This means that header and scrollbar together may be higher than your window and 30px of the dropdown will be missing on your device and you won\'t be able to see them since there is no scrollbar."'
b'b" How reliable is in media queries? If it works OK
column11: we could set different values for the drawer for shallower and deeper screens. I\'ve only set in media queries on sites I\'ve built
column12: so I can\'t say whether this is a viable solution."'

column10: b"b' I tend to go back to the Bootstrap default and have a scrollbar there if the dropdown is too high.'"

column10: b"b' Error 500 when posting an invalid link'"
b"b' I tried to post the following comment: on the post itself (so referencing a post in one of its comments) url  and I got a 500:  '"
b'b" First: links are not supported yet from many pods
column11: so it\'s not recommended to use them yet. When they are supported from enough pods they will be created automatically from the frontend when you add a pod-local link (this functionality will be added in a future release).  Second: Your link is invalid
column12: that\'s why it fails. It should be  . This wouldn\'t be a problem when it would be automatically generated from the frontend."'

column10: b'b\' Hm
column11: I get your point
column12: but I still feel like diaspora* should return an error message saying "posts" entity is unknown instead of a 500
column13: don\\\'t you think so?\''

column10: b'b" No
column11: because users shouldn\'t create these links by hand. And a users wouldn\'t understand such error message. And adding a validation to return a special error message for a special case which should never happen would only add complexity at a place where it shouldn\'t be."'

column10: b"b' Fair enough.'"
b'b" Shouldn\'t we just ignore invalid URLs? I\'m even unable to submit the following text as a comment: "'
b'b" Yes
column11: you\'re right
column12: we should ignore  urls."'

column12: but it is toatally valid  url  The GUID be47b074a97485fd3d5660da05407137d0414fbef8ce3300e9b8f4d187cccd8f@ is  * 77 chars long (>16; < 255) * contains only letters
column13: numbers @ and . which are all allowed * ends with  so I\'d guess it is diasporas issue not hubzillas :)  I remembered deadsuperhero did something similar once

Oh  ### How to reproduce:  * Search for holger@ on your diaspora\\\\*-pod * Open a post in single-view * Click the timestamp to get the post with the GUID in single view * 404  Want to back this issue? **[Post a bounty on it!]url  We accept bounties via [Bountysource]url  "'

column10: b'b\' GUIDs from  never worked for showing posts
column11: I think it\\\'s at least the dots which are a problem for how rails handles URLs and the last dot is used to split the
column12: I don\\\'t know if there are more problems with it. About valid and invalid:  In the past (many years ago) there was no validation at all. It was "worked" oder "didn\\\'t work". And the GUIDs from hubzilla (and redmatrix) "worked". When rewriting the federation and adding validations
column13: I "allowed" everything that "worked" in the past
column14: otherwise we would have blocked all communication from hubzilla because everything which isn\\\'t valid would be rejected now. And since it works for the federation part
column15: I didn\\\'t see a reason to block it (even I knew that it never worked for the display part
column16: but since diaspora usually uses the ID to display posts
column17: that shouldn\\\'t be a problem).  However
column18: I have no idea if this is fixable with rails and if we can change the behavior of how rails parses it
column19: so we can make posts from hubzilla also work with GUIDs and not only with IDs.\''

column10: b'b" It\'s fixable if we give up the dot-format syntax for that endpoint. That is would no longer work and to get the JSON representation you\'d be left with the header only."'
b'b"  Ah okay
column11: I see. Well maybe it would be a good idea to prohibit it in the spec but still be tollerant on the reading side of the applications protocol. url  This way softwares using the protocol would be forced to somehow escape the dots (maybe replace them by underscore or another character the spec allowes or diaspora\\\\* allows a new one). But those which don\'t would still be accepted on the federation side and still not work for display (but this for reasons\\xe2\\x80\\xa6 because they are invalid). I cannot believe this type of bug isn\'t fixable in any turing complete language XD Since I have no idea about ruby nor RoR I have no idea what\'s the best way to fix this. The simplest I pointed out above (just change the spec and keep everything else as it is). Maybe @jhass suggestion is a good one or to add a format-string to the end of the link (like .html or whatever) or maybe replace every in a GUID by a when it comes to hyperlinks.  By the way\\xe2\\x80\\xa6 if I understand you two right
column12: this **should** work (but it doesn\'t)  url the format now is clear by the .json so\\xe2\\x80\\xa6 shouldn\'t the rest be taken as guid?"'

column10: b'b" IIRC the format is eager
column11: so here it would be  .  I mean having both certainly is possible with the right regular expression at the route. I\'m just not sure if it isn\'t too brittle
column12: what if somebody sends us as a guid?"'

column10: b'b"  That\'s fine for me
column11: our frontend sends the header and I think we don\'t use the of the post anyway (that\'s already included in the  . But I think some users will complain when the stops working
column12: as they already did for
column13: but since that\'s not a public API I think it\'s OK to change that. Yes
column14: I think it\'s fixable (everything is fixable with more or less effort)
column15: but I didn\'t know how easy it is
column16: or if we need to write a big and ugly workaround for that to work. Also it isn\'t a problem of the language
column17: it\'s a problem of the framework. But of course you can write another framework with the same language without this behavior and you wouldn\'t have the problem
column18: but I think that\'s not an option here ;) That doesn\'t work
column19: browsers replace them back to and it doesn\'t work anymore (which would end in weird bugreports when it sometimes work but not always).  But when @jhass has an easy way to disable the format for this route
column20: then I think that\'s a doable solution :)"'

column10: b"b' Mentioning does not work in bio'"
b'b" Hey
column11: maybe this works as intended
column12: but I just recognized I cannot mention accounts in a profiles bio. Of coarse usually nobody wants to **mention** someone so the account gets notified etc. but maybe someone likes to link to another users profile.  So was my case: I created a sock puppet / twink account / bot / test account -thingy (so just an account that isn\'t my main account) and to make this transparent I wrote to the bio  That is interesting because the were removed :-o  Like I said\\xe2\\x80\\xa6 maybe it\'s not meant to be able to mention accounts in bio but as a user I would expect I can mention everywhere I can use markdown.  Want to back this issue? **[Post a bounty on it!]url  We accept bounties via [Bountysource]url  "'

column10: b'b" To me it makes some sense that mentioning doesn\'t work in bios
column11: because these are not communications in the sense that posts
column12: comments and conversations are
column13: and the person mentioned would thus not be able to respond. And would they get a notification when \'mentioned\' in a bio? About what?  The only case I can see for mentions in bios is to make it slightly more convenient to do the markdown  . To me it makes sense not to have mentions enabled here
column14: as there would be no action performed than making a link to the account profile; just use the standard link markdown code instead."'

column10: b"b' Agree
column11: what you want to do here is a link
column12: not a mention
column13: so please use the link syntax ;)'"

column10: b'b"  I thought the same first
column11: but the relative link @goobertron suggest has the same problems as any relative links on diaspora:  * It only works on diaspora
column12: everywhere else it links to a 404. * If the linked target isn\'t known
column13: it links to a 404.  And I think that linking to a profile from a bio is a valid use-case and using something that already exists and users already know maybe isn\'t that bad? We don\'t need the notifications
column14: but otherwise a mention would work perfectly. And it would also have advantages for the protocol
column15: because that way every text with Markdown would support the same .  An alternative would be to do something with  -URLs but that would be something special again (currently we don\'t support linking to profiles that way
column16: and also don\'t support of fetching profiles with it).  Since I think that\'s a valid feature-request and we don\'t provide a proper solution for this yet
column17: I\'m reopening this."'
